PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by WA Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Company Tax Collection System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's Budget decision to change the company tax collection system will be a crippling blow to many small businesses, already suffering as a direct result of the Hawke Labor Government's high interest rate policy.
The earlier remittance of company tax payments to the Government will substantially reduce the cash-flow position of thousands of small businesses.

Many small businesses will be driven under as a result of the Government's decision-unable to find funds for both tax commitments and new stock, only able to borrow at record high interest rates and unable to claim any tax relief on such borrowings to meet their tax commitment.
The Government's proposed changes to the company tax collection system has only been introduced as a greedy grab for more tax revenue.

The small business community would prefer the Government to completely abandon the proposal rather than make only minor alterations to the original Budget decision, which are not likely to alleviate the situation to any significant extent.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Deaths in Custody
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned Australian petitioners call on the Australian Government to take real steps to prevent the abuse of human rights of Aboriginals in prison and police custody.

A Royal Commission was set up to find out in general terms why so many Aborigines die in custody and the circumstances surrounding each death before the Commission. We the petitioners, would like to express the following concerns:

1. Aboriginal families and organisations have not received adequate funding from the Federal Government to ensure adequate representation. Yet the Commission faces constant challenge from the powerful police and prison officers' unions in their efforts to shut down the inquiry.

2. The Royal Commission's interim report includes recommendations for changes in custodial practices. Yet only some of the recommendations have been implemented and only in some places-no government body is monitoring the implementation and the deaths continue.
3. The occurrence of racist attacks, ie: David Gundy was killed in his home by the Police SWOS. The Coroner's Court verdict on his killing was `death by accident'.
We call for a just inquiry into Aboriginal deaths in custody.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's attack upon the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme has cast grave doubts over the future viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide much-needed service to the community, including particularly those in rural areas;
The proposed changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will further jeopardise the viability of pharmacists;
The latest decision to slash PBS payments to pharmacists by an average of $1.05 per script is simply unacceptable and will force the closure of many pharmacies.

Your petitioners respectfully request that the Senate urge the Government to ensure adequate remuneration levels for pharmacists, so that they may be able to provide a high quality health care service which is the right of every citizen of Australia.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

This humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully draws the attention of the Senate to the Government's attack on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, which has severely affected the viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide the quality and quantity of services to which we as Australians have a right.

Your petitioners respectfully request the Senate to urge the Government to guarantee an adequately funded Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, so as to ensure the continued viability of neighbourhood pharmaceutical services through our local community pharmacies.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The proposed cuts in funding to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will have serious effects on the viability of many family chemists, leading to increased charges and reduction in services and availability of medicines to the community.
We therefore call on the Federal Government to reject the findings of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal and maintain the level of funding existing prior to the Tribunal's findings.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tasmania: VHF/UHF Transmission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned residents of Tasmania respectfully showeth:
That the mountainous terrain and geography of Tasmania makes VHF television transmissions the most suitable for the State;
That more than 30,000 Tasmanians will have to purchase new television receivers and new antennae if commercial television in the State is forced to change from the VHF to the UHF band;

Your petitioners therefore request that the requirement by the Department of Transport and Communications to force Tasmania's two commercial television stations to change from the VHF to the UHF band by 1993 be immediately rescinded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

(b) notes his comment that, if the proportion of white prisoners dying in custody since 1980 equalled that of blacks, the number would be 6000;

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, will be absent from the chamber for the remainder of this period of sittings on official Government business overseas. Senator Evans will be travelling to eastern Europe to assess the political events there and their implications for Australia. The Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, will also be absent from the chamber until Thursday on official Government business. Senator Cook will be signing the Timor Gap treaty with Indonesia and attending meetings of the National Liaison Group for the North West Shelf project and the Iron Ore Industry Consultative Council. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Evans in relation to his portfolio or those he represents should be directed to Senator Robert Ray. Those questions which would normally be directed to Senator Cook in relation to his portfolio and primary industries and energy matters should be directed to Senator Walsh. Those questions in relation to community services and health matters should be directed to Senator Bolkus.
—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Will conditions allow for a lowering of interest rates before the end of the financial year?
—It is about six years since I was invited to speculate on what would happen to interest rates in the future. I have declined to speculate on every occasion since then, and I will continue to do so.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health been drawn to a claim by an international environment group that between 1,000 and 4,000 people die each year from lung cancer caused by the radioactive gas radon, which is trapped in modern insulated houses? Can the Minister advise whether similar conditions occur with Australian insulation methods? Is the gas radon causing any concern to health authorities?

—I do have an answer for Senator Colston. Essentially I am informed that radon occurs naturally in the environment and that the decay of radon contributes to the natural background of radiation to which people are generally exposed. The Department of Community Services and Health has been unable to obtain details of the particular claim referred to in the honourable senator's question. However, the National Radiological Protection Board of the United Kingdom has estimated that in that country up to 1,500 lung cancer deaths per annum might be attributed to radon. To put that figure into perspective, there are over 34,000 lung cancer deaths per annum in the United Kingdom and most of these are caused by smoking. I am informed that the existence of basements and well-sealed homes in the United Kingdom is likely to lead to higher levels of exposure to radon in that country than would occur in Australia. However, a survey of radon levels in Australian homes is being carried out by the Australian Radiation Laboratory. We anticipate that that survey will be completed by mid-1990. In conclusion, preliminary results show that average Australian indoor radon levels are below world average standards.

—Is the Minister representing the Prime Minister concerned that the Prime Minister's comments on Friday, about the prospect of an easing in monetary policy leading to lower interest rates, may encourage many Australians to believe that the worst is over? Would the Minister agree that it would be totally counterproductive if such comments sparked a renewed bout of consumption?

—All the indicators relating to consumption and consumption intentions suggest that there is no new bout of excessive consumption expenditure in the offing, particularly in relation to figures on retail trade and so on. The Prime Minister made no comments about interest rates as such. He referred to the conditions which may exist for a lowering of interest rates and the need to watch the various economic indicators and to be sure that the economy is slowing sufficiently before there can be an easing in monetary policy. He did say that anecdotal evidence-and I stress `anecdotal evidence'-suggests that the economy is gradually slowing. As I said last week, I think all that indicates is that there is a potential for a reduction in interest rates at the appropriate time, and that is not inconsistent with what the Prime Minister said. I think anybody who based wild anticipations of indulging in an orgy of consumption on the basis of that sort of comment would be, to say the least, not prudent.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the Minister aware of an article in the Australian Financial Review of Thursday, 7 December indicating that the Greiner Government has decided to delay the introduction of its radical industrial relations policy because of strong opposition from employer organisations? What is the nature of the opposition from these employer organisations? Are there any implications in this widespread rejection of the proposals for the Federal Government's industrial relations policy and for those proposed by the Federal Opposition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the Greiner Government has delayed the introduction of its industrial relations legislation, which was heralded a month or so ago as the major initiative of that Government in the last quarter of 1989. There has, I think, been some opposition to that proposed legislation from the trade union movement. There has also been somewhat strident opposition from the New South Wales Employers Federation, the Metal Trades Industry Association Inc. (MTIA), the New South Wales division of the Chamber of Manufactures, and the Law Society of New South Wales, which has also expressed serious reservations about the legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not know what that means in terms of New South Wales politics and what the Greiner Government proposes to do about that. A lot of the opposition has already been indicated in the Federal sphere by organisations such as the MTIA. I guess the implications of all of this are that it is very difficult to take a leap in the dark with changes like this and to try to anticipate what the consequences will be. A variety of organisations of the kind which I have mentioned are very cautious about the likely consequences. For example, while there may be agreement about some sort of shift in focus in moving the industrial relations scene closer to the enterprise over time, there are quite competing views as to how that should be done and how quickly it might be achieved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that all we are arguing about? We are only arguing about how we get there now, are we?

—I did not say that. I said that that is an argument between the participants of the kind to which I referred, particularly organisations such as the MTIA I know Senator Chaney has had a discussion with the MTIA about the Opposition's policy and claims that--
—You would not pay any attention to the MTIA, would you?

—I hope that Senator Stone's interjection will be recorded in Hansard. He said, `You would not pay any attention to the MTIA, would you?'. I want to make it quite clear that I would, and the implication of his interjection is that he would not. That should be made quite clear for the record.

ANSWER.PARA: The MTIA, which is one of the organisations in New South Wales referred to, is keen on shifting slowly to a more industry-based approach, but within the parameters of the existing centralised wage fixing system. That organisation has a more national focus than the Chamber of Manufactures of New South Wales, the Law Society of New South Wales and organisations such as those have. It is much more involved in the national debate and has cautioned a great deal about the sudden approach to these issues which, I believe, is inherent in the Opposition's policies. The relevance of the New South Wales experience is that, while it might have provided a useful test bed for a particular point of view about changes to the industrial relations system, that test bed seems to have been abandoned for the time being, and we cannot draw any practical conclusions from it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN REPRESENTATION TO THE HOLY SEE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to the recent visit by President Gorbachev to meet Pope John Paul II. I also refer him to reports in today's media that the Pope has sent his special envoy to continue talks with the Hungarian authorities on restoring diplomatic relations cut in 1945. In light of the improving relations between eastern European countries, the Soviet Union and the Vatican, will the Australian Government also look at upgrading Australia's representation to the Holy See to the status of a resident ambassador?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that Mr Gorbachev and the Pope had some fairly productive discussions which may lead to a far better relationship between the Holy See, eastern Europe and the Soviet Union-much better than that with Stalin who, when he heard of criticism by the Pope, asked `How many divisions does the Pope have?'. Relationships have improved a lot since then. Australia's diplomatic representations to the Holy See is covered by the Ambassador to Ireland who, I understand, makes reasonably frequent trips to that area in Australia's interests.
—Couldn't you find an honest man to send to the Pope?

—Senator Macklin may be a very well qualified candidate for this position. He should have declared his self-interest before he asked the question. I will certainly pass on his suggestion to the Acting Foreign Minister, Mr Duffy, and also, maybe, my suggestion that he should be considered for the post given his expert knowledge in these sorts of areas.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. Has the Minister seen a copy of a report by Dr T. Norton of the Centre for Resource and Environmental Studies at the Australian National University in which Dr Norton severely criticises the Forestry Commission of New South Wales in relation to the surveys conducted on koala habitat in Tantawangalo which, he says, cast doubt on the integrity of other recent surveys undertaken by the Forestry Commission in the region? In view of the Government's much heralded draft strategy for endangered species, and its intervention in the south-east forests through the joint State-Federal Biological Resources Study, will the Minister consider urging New South Wales Natural Resources Minister, Ian Causley, to compel the Forestry Commission to fulfil the requirements of the New South Wales Forestry Act? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the likely timetable for the establishment of National Estate protection legislation in the event that this disappointing performance by the Forestry Commission is repeated in National Estate areas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a copy of the report, dated 28 October, with me and I will quote, briefly, some passages from it. Firstly, after Dr Norton had walked around the bush for a while, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: No Koalas were seen.
The second quotation is:
it is highly probable that Compartment 2453, that was logged by the FC NSW was Koala habitat.
However, it is not possible, post-logging, to say unequivocally that the logged area was Koala habitat.

From those words, it seems that Dr Norton came to similar conclusions to those of the Forestry Commission of New South Wales. I do not know why he was criticising the New South Wales Forestry Commission.

In regard to the second part of the question, I think that we need something more conclusive than Dr Norton's words that it is not possible to say unequivocally one thing or another. In regard to the third part of the question, I am informed that the Government's view is that National Estate protection is regarded as adequate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government. It follows the question asked of the Minister for Finance regarding interest rates. I preface my question by noting the cautious response of the Minister for Finance.
—As always.

—It reflects, too, the cautious response of the Leader of the Government in the Senate last Thursday when a similar area of questioning was raised with him. I ask: How much weight should the Australian people attach to the Prime Minister's prediction on television on Friday that conditions which would allow an easing in interest rates would exist as we go into 1990? Is this latest promise any different from the Prime Minister's predictions in Perth in January that interest rates would fall before the end of this calendar year?

—The answer to the first part of the question is: a lot of weight, given the qualifications which the Prime Minister put on his comments. I repeat that he said that signs are emerging that conditions will exist for a lowering of interest rates; anecdotal evidence suggests that the economy is gradually slowing; and we have to be certain that the economy is slowing sufficiently before monetary policy can be eased. In that sense I must say that I regard that as different from any previous statement made by the Prime Minister, and it carries a lot of weight.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I think that the Leader of the Government and I are referring to different interviews. I refer him to the interview on A Current Affair on 8 December when, in part, the Prime Minister was asked:

QUESTION.PARA: Yet you still held out the promise of lower interest rates. When will that happen and how long will they stay down?
After answering questions at great length, as we all know, and going on about single measures and all the rest of it, the Prime Minister then responded:

Government has cut its expenditures, the restraint has been exercised by the community, interest rates have played their part, and I believe that as we go into 1990, that evidence will become stronger and the conditions will be there for a lowering of interest rates.

That seems to be a pretty blunt and direct statement about the conditions that will apply in 1990. I ask the Minister whether we are to put the weight of normal grammatical meaning on those words or is he seeking to qualify them on behalf of the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have anything to add to the answer I gave before. All Senator Chaney has done is put to me a different set of words which go to exactly the same points as the words I used in referring to the Prime Minister's speech the other night. I have nothing to add to what I said earlier.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Finance. I draw the Minister's attention to recent comments made by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, about a Liberal government's ability to lower interest rates and still manage Australia's foreign debt. Among other things, Mr Peacock stated that the Opposition's fiscal policy would restrain demand and, hence, interest rates could be lowered. In light of Mr Peacock's optimism, in contrast to the view of some of his colleagues, does the Government now intend to adopt the approach to fiscal policy proposed by the Opposition? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Foreman's question referred to Mr Peacock's statement that the Opposition's fiscal policy would restrain demand. If one believes the estimates made by the Opposition, the surplus would be increased by about $150m. However, one could not and should not believe one of the major components of the Opposition's economic statement, which was made a couple of weeks ago, because the savings on long term unemployed special benefits are grossly overestimated. The more likely effect of the Opposition's fiscal policy would be to reduce the Budget surplus by a few hundred million dollars. I do not want to quibble unduly about that because the plain fact is that a couple of hundred million dollars in either direction represents such a small change in fiscal policy that it would have a negligible effect on macro-economic outcomes or on the need for changes in other policies.

ANSWER.PARA: Therefore, there is no possibility of the Opposition's fiscal policy producing an outcome significantly different from the Government's fiscal policy. We have Opposition spokespeople running around all over the place promising to spend more money and giving additional expenditure commitments that are not allowed for in the economic policy statement. If one ignores all that pork-barrelling and deception and just looks at the Opposition's official document, one sees that it represents, so far as fiscal policy aggregates are concerned, no substantial compositional differences, but I do not want to go into them just now. I might discuss them a little in the debate on the matter of public importance.

Mr Peacock is always saying something or other, and with increasing frequency he is then contradicted by Senator Stone or Mr Howard, or even by Senator Hill, who had to explain to Mr Peacock a couple of months ago what a `trading bloc' actually meant. Apparently, Mr Peacock was as ignorant of that term, which refers to people dealing in international trade, as he is, on his own admission, ignorant of the principles of accountancy. I do not know whether anybody really takes much notice of what Mr Peacock says about anything these days. His own words could be used as a response to any question at all arising from anything he has said-`Who knows'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Prime Minister and Minister for Industrial Relations tell the Senate what happened between 20 August, when the Prime Minister promised full support for legal action and potentially drastic financial penalties on the pilots' union, and last Thursday, when the same Prime Minister said that imposing damages on the Australian Federation of Air Pilots was not his `cup of tea'? Apart from union outrage and back-bench trembles, what other factors caused the Prime Minister so dramatically to change his attitude to the Pilots' Federation?

—It would be fairly obvious to most people that the circumstances of the pilots dispute with the airlines have changed considerably. Of necessity, the Government had to adopt a very firm attitude to what was an outrageous claim in August. The Government's position on that in support of the airlines' view of that claim was made quite clear at the time by the Prime Minister amongst others. In the last week or so, with the airlines increasing the number of services they are offering and, hopefully, with considerable progress being made in the Industrial Relations Commission, I think anybody would understand the statement made by the Prime Minister in his speech at the National Press Club last week. One does not have to be a genius to see that that is both a common-sense and correct approach in the current circumstances.

—I ask a supplementary question. Does the Prime Minister support punitive legal action of the nature taken by the airline industry under all circumstances or under some circumstances? And what are the circumstances if they are qualified?

—The position adopted by the Government in relation to common law damages being sought against unions is that that is a remedy which exists in law and which can and should only be used in the most extreme circumstances after all other remedies have been exhausted, and that is, in a sense, the view of the courts.
—They had not been exhausted when the Prime Minister made that wild statement of support. There was no qualification then.

—I am not saying that. What I am saying is that there were extreme circumstances at that time, clearly indicated by the Pilots Federation and understood by everybody in the community, except the Liberal Opposition. It was a situation in which the Pilots Federation had said that it was ready for a long strike, that it wanted 30 per cent or nothing and that it would not consider productivity claims by the airlines. All those circumstances have been spelt out in the Pilots Federation journal and other publications of that organisation. It was quite clear that the pilots were hell-bent on creating very difficult circumstances and were ready for the long haul, if necessary.
—That is exactly what they said in 1974 when Bob Hawke--

—That is what was said in 1974 and in a number of other years. Mostly governments of those other years caved in to them. In 1974, or in any intervening year between 1974 and 1983, there was no centralised wage fixing system accepted by the community as a whole.
—In 1974 Bob Hawke told Charlie Jones to butt out.

—The honourable senator ought to make a speech on the adjournment about this. If he wants to hear the answer to the question, perhaps he could listen. If he raises this matter on the adjournment, I will make sure that I am not here.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that the newly developed chlorofluorocarbon recovery units which recycle CFCs from refrigerators and air-conditioners are playing a major role in reducing these emissions to the atmosphere? Why then is not the Government offering some incentive to the main users of these units, tradespeople and industry? Why does the 20 per cent sales tax still remain despite the intensive lobbying by State governments and industry? Finally, is the Minister aware that interim replacement of high ozone depleting CFCs-that is, CFC 11 and CFC 12, with the less destructive HCFC 22-is likely to be difficult due to the high running costs of the compressors? Why does not the Federal Government consider offering an incentive, as has been done in Sweden, and impose a levy on the high ozone depleting CFCs to make the more expensive alternatives more attractive?

—This question comes from Senator Vallentine, the peacenik who joined the Country Party during the Vietnam War. At that time the alleged danger or threat was the downward thrust of China. The knee-jerk response to it was to send Australian conscripts to Vietnam. That was in the mid-1960s when Senator Vallentine joined the Country Party. She has since then, of course, been metamorphosised from a hawke into a dove, but she retains her commitment to knee-jerk simplistic responses to perceived or alleged problems. For example, the second part of her question referred to the high running costs of compressors which use a different gas and cause less ozone damage; in other words, a more energy intensive technology. If we are going to adopt more energy intensive technologies, we are going to require more electricity, and more electricity requires more coal to be burned and this creates more carbon dioxide.
—I find that hard to believe.

—There is, of course, an alternative, Senator Chaney. The question referred to Sweden. The Swedes may be able to do this without adding to carbon dioxide emissions because they use quite a lot of nuclear energy as well as hydro-energy. Indeed, when I was in Sweden a few years ago I found that the Swedes get very annoyed and angry when they are sanctimoniously preached at by the Danes, just as those of us who were opposing the Vietnam War got rather annoyed when we were sanctimoniously preached at by latter-day peaceniks. The Swedes get very angry because they export nuclear-generated electricity to Denmark and import acid rain from Denmark caused by the burning of sulphurous coal. The Swedes reckon that it is really a bit rough when the Danes preach to them about the evils of generating nuclear electricity, which the Swedes export to Denmark, while importing acid rain in return. In regard to the first part of the question, I understand that the Treasurer has not yet considered advice on the matter. Despite the usual plethora of conceptual and logic flaws, misconceptions and sloppy thinking in the question, I am pleased to see that at last people like Senator Vallentine have begun to realise that there might be a role for economic principles in dealing with environmental policies.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Minister will recall saying last week that he hoped the issue which had closed Mobil's Altona oil refinery in Victoria for the past five weeks would be resolved as quickly as possible. Is the Minister aware that, despite the fact that there have been five inspections to check asbestos levels at the plant, despite the fact that State Government health authorities have cleared the site, and despite a vote on Friday by 600 contract workers to return to work, the refinery remains closed because 60 maintenance employees are demanding yet another inspection by yet another consultant? If this situation continues, will the Government give the same unequivocal backing to the company, should it decide to proceed with common law and trade practices actions that it has foreshadowed, that the Prime Minister gave to the employers in the pilots dispute?

—I will direct that question to the Minister for Industrial Relations and obtain an answer for the honourable senator as soon as possible. I understand that common law proceedings have been commenced by the employers at Altona. I am not sure, but I believe that it was part of the negotiations leading to the return of the 600 workers on Saturday that those proceedings should not continue. Maybe I am wrong about that, but I will obtain an updated answer and give it to the honourable senator as soon as possible.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security seen the report of the Sydney City Mission entitled Prisoners of Poverty? What is the Government's response to the issues highlighted by the report? What are the implications, if any, for the Government's family and social policies?|

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not gone through the report comprehensively, but I understand that the link between poverty and other social problems forms the basis of the core point made in the report. It, of course, mentions the questions of domestic violence, and drug and alcohol abuse. The core point of the report is that poverty, as the Government acknowledges, is a multidimensional problem. It should be recognised that the report acknowledges the fact that income support is one of a number of critical factors in attacking family poverty. However, it makes the point that it is not the only important factor. The provision of services is one area that cannot and should not be ignored.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the first point, the question of income support measures, it should be noted and recognised that the Government's record in this area is one that we will build on. It is also recognised as being outstanding. We have introduced family allowance supplements (FAS), which are targeted very much to the areas of poverty. We have achieved the family allowance supplement benchmarks. The April family package reformed and increased the family allowance, and the inflation adjustment system of the entire family income support system is, for the first time in Australia's history, recognised as being vital to the maintenance of income support.

In terms of the effect of these measures, it should be recognised that over 3.7 million children in two million families are now receiving the new family allowance rates. As importantly, over 1.2 million children in half a million families now receive FAS or its equivalent. Bishop Peter Hollingworth said:
For the first time in this country's history, we have a system of guaranteed minimum income for children.

This historic achievement has been widely acknowledged. The Government also acknowledges the core point of the report; that is, that the causes and symptoms of poverty are far wider than pure economics. The Minister for Social Security has said this time and time again. As recognised, the provision of services by Commonwealth, State and local governments is crucial, as is the provision of services by community organisations. The Economic Planning and Advisory Council recognises this as well. In its most recent report it states:
Income support measures alone are not sufficient to deal with the broader aspects of poverty that exist in the Australian community. A broader range of other social policies will also be necessary.

This link between poverty and the need for adequate services-has also been recognised by the Government. Elements of the social wage are obviously crucial in meeting the problems that have been highlighted by the report. Aspects such as Medicare, schools, increasing retention rates in schools, employment policies, and new child-care places all have a role to play. There is also a role for especially targeted multi-dimensional initiatives of government such as the jobs, education and training program, Newstart and the youth social justice strategy.

In summary, as I have said, the report makes a very strong point of the need for all levels of government and the community to recognise that poverty is very much a multi-dimensional problem and to give adequate attention to it. The Government's bottom line is that the attack on poverty is no easy task to undertake. But we have demonstrated that we do have the courage, the commitment and the record--

—I refer the Minister for Consumer Affairs to reports that Australian consumers are being deprived of information about ingredients constituting cosmetic products. Is it a fact that consumers in other countries, including the United States, are able to purchase cosmetics with full ingredient labelling information on the packages? Can the Minister say whether the Australian Government is able to ensure that an adequate degree of ingredient labelling can be introduced for the Australian consumer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question that Senator Giles raises goes to an industry which has a weekly consumption value of $31m and an annual consumption value of $1.6 billion, covering cosmetics and toiletries. As I have indicated, it is a large industry and, as such, it affects quite a number of people. Consumers of all ages and both sexes are interested in the degree of information that is made available to them when they buy cosmetics or toiletries. There are three reasons that come to mind immediately for the need for ingredient labelling of these products. At this stage we do not have compulsory ingredient labelling or even a voluntary agreement, but, succinctly put, the reasons for having labelling are, firstly, consumers need to know what is in the product they purchase in order to compare products; secondly, they need to know what is in the product so that they can compare the price of products; and, thirdly, a growing concern amongst a number of people that quite often there are allergic reactions to ingredients in cosmetics and toiletries.

ANSWER.PARA: For those reasons, the Government has for some time been consulting with community, industry and consumer groups on how we can respond to this problem. We are assessing in one arm of government the question of allergies. In another there has been discussion on ingredient labelling. The Trade Practices Commission has also been discussing with industry a code of conduct to ensure coverage of advertising, in-store promotion, packaging and product recall of cosmetics. I have been able to announce today that under section 65d of the Trade Practices Act we will be developing a standard to ensure full ingredient labelling of cosmetic products. The standard will also cover a requirement for a manufactured on or use by date, and will ensure that there will be adequate information about the manufacturer or supplier of the product involved. This degree of information should address the problems that have been faced by a community which has been shopping in the dark in this area. I anticipate that the standard will be developed by early 1990 and will have effect thereafter.

The vital consideration is to ensure that a suitable lead-in period is made available to industry to adjust to this standard. It should be noted-and I think Senator Giles's question mentioned this-that other countries, in particular the United States, already have standards in place to ensure that there is full ingredient labelling in this area. The same product may be packaged differently in the United States-in one way for domestic purposes and in another for export to Australia, the product for export to Australia not having anywhere near the degree of information that is available to United States consumers. Consultations will continue as to the form of the standard. There are some questions as to the ambit and the form of listing of the products involved. One question we have to resolve is whether we go by recognisable ingredient names or code numbers. But those problems will be addressed in the next few weeks. We anticipate that in February-March next year a defined standard will be made available for the community which consumers can see as the benchmark for their rights to information in this area in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 December Senator MacGibbon asked me a question about some comments on the Australian Customs Service in the Australian Financial Review of 4 December. I have obtained an answer to that question. As it is somewhat long, I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

The document read as follows-

The Honourable Senator's question appears to stem from a report in the Australian Financial Review, dated 4 December 1989, in which it quotes Mr Justice Davies of the Federal Court of Australia as saying that the decision not to immediately repay money to LNC Limited, an importer recently involved with litigation with the ACS, was a `dirty' and `shabby' act.

The newspaper in fact misquoted his Honour. The Judge did not in fact say that the ACS was `dirty' and `shabby' in not repaying the money to the applicant but rather was quoting a statement made by Lord Bridge of the House of Lords, delivering a judgment in the case of Tower Hamlets Borough Council v. Chetnik Developments Pty. Ltd appearing in volume 1 of the All England Law Reports at page 969. That case dealt with whether or not government officials had an obligation to repay monies paid to a Government agency as a result of errors of law-a question that was only one small part of the LNC litigation.

In the ten years or so that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has had jurisdiction over disputes involving amounts or rates of duty Customs has never refused to repay monies that have been paid under protest when an applicant has been finally successful before the Tribunal or, on appeal, before the Federal Court.

With regards to the particular queries of the Honourable Senator, I advise that LNC actually paid an amount of $7551.80 in cash under protest; this amount will be repaid to the applicant during the course of this week. Not all this security is required to be repaid because of Justice Davies' judgment. The level of security that is to be discharged because of LNC's partially successful action is now being assessed and will be determined at the earliest possible time.

As to the second question, I should like to inform the Senate that every time the ACS passes an entry of goods for home consumption into Australia it is making, to use the terminology of the Honourable Senator, a `ruling'.

In 1988-1989 alone, throughout Australia there were 1,540,507 entries for home consumption lodged-about 6500 per working day. Of these decisions, a mere 48 have been referred to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or a Court during 1989. So far 26 decisions have been handed down-13 were set aside and 13 affirmed. A further 22 decisions have been settled by consent of the parties or are yet to be decided. I believe that this is clear evidence that the Government is living within its own customs legislation.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE: FLEET MAINTENANCE

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer to some questions asked of me by Senator Boswell on the maintenance contract for the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) C130 aircraft fleet. In looking at the answer to these questions, it is necessary to go through the sequential nature of the contracting, and I propose to do so. The request for tender was issued on 2 February 1989. Tenders were submitted to the Department of Defence on 27 April 1989. The tender evaluation was then undertaken and a recommendation made on 19 September. Negotiations commenced with the preferred tenderer on 18 October. The last negotiation was held in Melbourne on 27 November. The Minister for Defence announced the decision on 7 December. Following the negotiations, the contract has been completed and, after the Minister's announcement, it is expected to be sent to the winning company on or about 13 December 1989. The delay of a few days is due to some word processing difficulties.

ANSWER.PARA: Throughout these processes, tenderers are kept informed of progress, within the bounds of competition and probity, to enable them to plan their own activities and avoid potentially nugatory costs. In this case, the sequence of advice to Hawker de Havilland included: On 6 October it was advised that negotiations would be commencing shortly with Air New Zealand Ltd. On 24 October it was advised that `no contract has yet been arranged, and accordingly all tenders are still being considered. It is therefore not proposed to conduct any debriefings until successful tenderer has been selected'. There was debriefing in response to questions from the company on 4 December 1989 and a formal letter declining the company's offer will be sent at about the same time as the contract is sent to the winning company.

Meanwhile, Air New Zealand was advised on 17 November 1989 that its tender would be accepted `subject to the terms and conditions of . . . Contract PN 8002, which will be despatched shortly'. Negotiations on those terms and conditions were continuing on 27 November, as mentioned above.

The practice of informing companies that negotiations are to commence with another company-in this case, on 6 October-clearly tells them that they are not preferred. But they are given to understand-in this case, this was done formally on 24 October-that, should negotiations with the preferred tenderer not result in a satisfactory contract, they may be invited to negotiate. It is then for them to judge whether it is worth keeping people standing by. Obviously, their likelihood of being reconsidered changes as the various processes are progressed, and this influences their judgments.

The announcement of the winner or likely winner can occur at different stages in this process, depending on such things as the likelihood of a successful contract being concluded and any wider considerations such as levels of funding or relations with other countries. On some occasions the intention to negotiate with a particular company is announced; on others, no announcement is made until all contractual and other details are completely resolved. This is one of the latter cases. The final decision and announcement were not made until matters had been fully resolved because of the importance of our relationship with New Zealand and the strategic importance of the task.

Turning briefly to the outcome, one might note the substantial price difference of more than 10 per cent and the preference listed by the Minister on technical and contractual grounds. One might also note that, despite the distance, Air New Zealand offered a quicker turn around of aircraft sent for maintenance, which is of obvious benefit to the operations of the RAAF through increased aircraft availability.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter of public importance because since the Opposition brought down its Economic Action Plan on 12 October and since, in particular, the Government failed so signally to make any real responses to that plan-of course, the facts are that the Government has no policies apart from higher and higher interest rates-we have seen, from the Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia (Mr Keating) no less, a shameful campaign of disinformation in relation to one aspect of the Economic Action Plan, namely, the Opposition's announcement that it will repeal the Government's capital gains tax and replace it with a speculative gains tax in order, particularly, to help smaller businesses and encourage longer term investment and savings.

SPEECH.PARA: For the past six to eight weeks the Government's disinformation machine has been hard at work in its usual manner trying to sell the lie-I make no apology for using that word-that the coalition's proposed speculative gains tax will benefit only the rich. At the same time, the Australian Labor Party wants people to believe that its capital gain tax is equitable and fair. In fact, the opposite is the case: Labor's capital gains tax will adversely affect millions of Australians who in no way can be classed as rich while the coalition's proposal to replace that tax with a speculative gains tax will encourage more productive investment, thereby benefiting all Australians.

I am glad to see that there are at least three-I hesitate to say respectable-speakers from the Government side on the speakers list today who are worthy to be included in a matter of public importance debate. This is rather different from the Government's normal performance on these matters when it trots out speakers, whom I will not name as it would be invidious to do so, but who, to say the least, are not up to the job. I am glad that Senator Walsh is responding today. We will also hear from Senator McMullan and Senator Beahan. In view of the fact that five speakers on the list are either Western Australians or ex-Western Australians, there seems to be an almost Western Australian benefit. I do not quite know what conclusion I should draw from that. I expect to receive from Senator Walsh a more intellectually rigorous defence of an admittedly indefensible position on the Government's part than we would get from his shameless colleague the Treasurer on the same topic. Mr Keating, in the aftermath of the Opposition's Economic Action Plan, was in a state of great frustration, unable to attack any details of the plan. Indeed, he was silent for a whole week after it was brought down. He finally made a rather weak attempt to attack some of the figuring in the plan-a matter to which Senator Walsh fleetingly referred today. This, of course, once again dashed the Government's hopes of an early election, thereby forcing it to govern for another three or four months or perhaps longer while the economy slides out from underneath it.

It is perhaps because of that sense of increasing rage and frustration on Mr Keating's part that we had his notorious and totally defamatory attack in the other House upon Mr John Elliott. That attack was based upon no evidence whatsoever. It was merely an assertion that the Opposition's policy to repeal the capital gains tax was in some way for the purpose of benefiting Mr Elliott. It was inherently unbelievable because the facts are that the Opposition's policy was announced on 10 May last year by the then Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong, Mr Howard, and the then shadow Treasurer, Mr Peacock, and it was reconfirmed in exactly the same words in the Future Directions document in December last year. The share transactions, to which I have no doubt Senator Walsh will probably once again refer today, did not even come into the picture until the middle of this year. The Treasurer's attack was not only shameful in the sense of being totally unsubstantiated by any evidence but also inherently unbelievable because of the sequence of events. Subsequently Mr Keating has never seen fit to apologise for that. It would not occur to him. It is not within his nature. He is not man enough to stand up in the other place and apologise for something as shameful as that. He does not have the guts. Having been bested in that regard, Mr Keating was subsequently reduced to making the lame claim that, because of Mr Elliott's pressure, the Opposition had not abandoned its previously announced proposal. What a joke! It is ludicrous.

Let us look at the capital gains tax, which is, as many others have said, a form of death duty. This is a fact that the Government continues to deny but it is incontrovertibly true-it is a form of death duty. At the time of announcing the capital gains tax, Mr Keating said:
Liability for tax in the case of death will be rolled over to successors, and will only be assessed on any subsequent disposal. Therefore-
note that non sequitur-
the capital gains tax will not apply in the case of death.

That gives a totally misleading impression. The fact is that if, after the death of the person leaving the estate, the estate has to be split up between more than one beneficiary, it is often essential to sell the assets. That is fine if there is a single beneficiary and he or she wants the particular assets concerned, is prepared to carry on working the farm, wants the particular shares, or whatever. But if there is a need to divide the assets or if for some reason the person is not able to manage the farm-if that should be the nature of the asset-then it has to be sold, converted to cash and distributed. That process immediately results in the application of a capital gains tax. So in those circumstances, which are the most common-not uncommon-circumstances the tax does operate as a de facto death duty. The Government can go around this country saying that it does not until it is black in the face but the people know that it does.

There is also a claim that the capital gains tax does not apply to the principal private residence. The Government said it was careful to exclude the principal private residence from the application of the tax. But the fact is that there are many cases, again not uncommon, where the tax does apply. I have a whole list of such cases which, with the Minister's permission, I would like to have incorporated in Hansard. Let me just mention a couple. For example, taxpayers can claim only one property as their principal place of residence although two dwellings are permissible for up to three months where a taxpayer changes homes. Many thousands of Australians will be caught up in the situation where it takes longer than three months to sell their property. In that case, the capital gains tax comes into play on a pro rata basis. Here is another example: a home owner acquires a home to be used as a sole or a principal residence and places the first home on the market. In order to defray the high cost of bridging finance, perhaps, the first home is rented out. The ability to own two homes for up to three months is thereby denied under the law and the home becomes subject to the capital gains tax. I can go on quoting examples of that kind but I seek leave to incorporate all of them in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Circumstances where the Family Home may attract liability for the Capital Gains Tax.

(1) The capital gains tax exemption is based on the qualification that the family home be not used for income-producing purposes. If a member of the family pays rent or board, the family home will partially lose its exemption. Similarly, if the family home has a study used for work then a liability may be incurred. Ref: Sub-section 21.

(2) The sale of the family garden shed, storeroom or other structure, will be subject to capital gains tax. This includes the case where a father gives his son the portable tool shed from the garden. Ref: Sub-section 1, 3 and 4.
(3) Capital gains tax will apply to a new family home purchased by a young couple whilst still living with their parents before their marriage.

It will also apply to a young couple who are renting and who purchase a block for their family home. The young couple will find that the block is subject to capital gains tax. Ref: Sub-section (5e) and (f). This could occur as follows:

(4) The exemption is only available if upon completion of the new house it is occupied for at least 12 months. If for example, the young couple have to move (for work reasons) within 12 months then the exemption is lost.

(5) The maximum exemption-free time allowed under Sub-section 5 (f) is 4 years. If because they are building themselves, or they are not saving fast enough and the time lapse between acquisition and occupation exceeds 4 years, then the young couple will have to pay capital gains tax on a pro rata basis.
(6) If the block is purchased by the young couple prior to their marriage and if one or both of them are, during that time, dependent on a parent then for that period the block will not be exempt.

(7) If the family home is on more than 2 hectares, then the excess over 2 hectares is subject to capital gains tax. Many people will be caught up by this provision, particularly in outer metropolitan areas where blocks in excess of 2 hectares are very popular. The Assets Test fiasco showed how difficult questions of valuation become, particularly where stringent town planning controls are in force.

(8) If the family home is in excess of 2 hectares and you allow a neighbour to put in a drain at the back of your property, then you are liable for capital gains tax even though you receive no payment from your neighbour. The creation of de facto de jure easements is very common and this particular provision will cause many headaches.
(9) Where the family home is on a block less than 2 hectares but which is still big enough to subdivide, then any land subdivided off will be subject to capital gains tax. Ref: Sub-session 4.

(10) To claim the tax exemption for land that is adjacent to the family home even where the home is on less than 2 hectares, the land must be used primarily for private or domestic purposes. If this is not the case the land will be taxable regardless of its size. Ref: Sub-section 3.

(11) The family home of a couple which is a unit or flat in a retirement village may not be exempt from capital gains tax unless the owners have a title, a lease or shares in the title holding. Ref: Sub-section 2.

(12) Taxpayers can claim only one property as their principal place of residence, although two dwellings are permissible for up to three months where a taxpayer changes homes. Many thousand of Australians will be caught up in the situation where it takes longer to sell property than they had realised. Ref: Sub-section 8.

(13) A home owner acquires a home to be used as a sole or principal residence and places the first home on the market. In order to defray the high costs of bridging finance the first home is rented out. The ability to own 2 homes for up to 3 months is thereby denied and the home will be subject to the capital gains tax.
(14) A capital gains tax is payable where the family home is owned by a discretionary trust. Ref: Sub-section 160zz8 and Sub-section 12.
(15) If you purchase a property and undertake renovations before taking up residence then the property will for that period be subject to capital gains tax.

(16) If you purchase a vacant block, construct a home on it and move in within 4 years then the land will be exempt from capital gains tax. But if you purchase a block with an old house on it, with the intent of demolishing the old house and building a new home on it then you will pay tax on the land until you occupy the new house.

(17) It is common in some states, e.g. Western Australia for display homes to be purchased as a principal residence. Often the builder will require a lease-back for up to 18 months. The capital gains tax will apply during this period.

(18) If a beneficiary of an estate inherits a dwelling that was the principal residence of a deceased no capital gains tax will be payable if the property is disposed of within 12 months. Tax will be payable if the sale is delayed beyond this time limit. Legal difficulties and red tape can often delay the finalization of an estate.

(19) Under the capital gains tax a home remains exempt in cases of temporary absences of up to 4 years. The exemption is only available if upon resuming residence the taxpayer notified the Commissioner ``in writing not later than the date of lodgement of the taxpayer's return of income for the year of income in which the dwelling again became the sole or principal residence of the taxpayer . . .''
If you are elderly and do not understand the complexities of the tax, or you simply forget you will pay the tax.
(20) If part of your property is compulsorily acquired for road widening purposes then the compensation will be subject to the tax. Ref: Sub-section 4 (a).

TALK.START.PARA: —It is worth while looking a little further at the effects of this exclusion of the principal private residence from capital gains tax. While obviously there are many sound reasons, not least political reasons, why that should be so, the fact is that that exclusion does create a preferred class of asset, namely, principal private residences. That has certain inexorable economic effects. The most important of these effects is that more and more people want to tie up a higher proportion of their assets in the principal private residence because they know that that will be one way of protecting them from the ravages of Mr Keating. Ever since this tax was introduced that has been going on with increasing force. We are seeing it in two ways: first, in the bidding up of housing prices; and, secondly, in the very sharp rise in the level of alterations and additions being made to houses. People are putting a second storey on their houses, adding another room, putting on a second garage-anything to tie up a higher proportion of their assets, in many cases, limited assets, in this form so that they will not be subject to Mr Keating's depredations. It is no good for the Government to say this is not happening, because it is. Anybody who asks people in the community about this will find out that it is happening.
—It's distorting the investment arrangements.

—It is totally distorting the investment arrangements and the capital market, as Senator Lewis quite rightly says. The most notorious example of this is, of course, Sydney, where a first home buyer today needs a salary-this has been calculated recently by the Real Estate Institution of Australia-of over $65,000 a year in order to meet the monthly requirements of a medium priced house financed by an average home loan. Only about 15 per cent of families in Australia would satisfy that test. Only four years ago, in September 1985 when the capital gains tax was introduced, the income needed for that same purpose was only $23,700, which was just above average weekly earnings at that time, whereas now it is about 2 1/4 times average weekly earnings.

SPEECH.PARA: How does one avoid this problem which the Government has created by its own tax? There are only two ways of avoiding it: either the Government includes the principal private residence within the ambit of the tax-in other words, it reverses the exclusion that it has made-or it abolishes the tax. The Opposition is promising to do the latter. The question is: Will the Government do the former? Will the Government, in fact, abolish the exclusion? The Government is set upon maintaining the capital gains tax. In order to get rid of this distortion from the capital market-the kind of thing which I would expect Senator Walsh to care about, for example, because he is an intellectually rigorous person in these matters-and in order to achieve that degree of rigour, will it therefore abolish the exclusion? Will it include the principal private residence within the ambit of the tax?

Mr Kelty of the Australian Council of Trade Unions has said recently that the ACTU wants to include any dwellings worth more than $1m within the ambit of the capital gains tax. One might say that that is a very small proportion of dwellings-although these days I suppose it is an increasingly large proportion, given the inflation in the cost of dwellings. But it is a foot in the door. I might say that, when the ACTU wants something from this Government, the ACTU usually gets it.
Who is affected by the capital gains tax? What did Mr Keating say about the capital gains tax originally? In a statement on 19 September 1985 he said:
As an illustration of the fact that this tax will affect only a tiny section of the population, its expected revenue yield in the fifth year of operation-
that is 1990-91, I think-
is estimated to be only $25m.

Of course, it is important to note that since that time there have been two major changes in the capital gains tax. The one we have today is not the same as that which was introduced by the Treasurer over four years ago. This is the death of a thousand cuts process, with which we are familiar from this Government. Firstly, on 20 May 1988 the Government decided to repeal section 26aaa of the Income Tax Assessment Act. That was the section which taxed, as short term speculative gain, transactions which took place within 12 months of each other. In other words, when an asset was sold within 12 months of its having been bought, any gain was taxed as income. On 25 May 1988 the Government repealed that and included such transactions within the ambit of the capital gains tax.

Secondly, and more importantly, from 1988-89 superannuation funds, which were not originally subject to the capital gains tax, were brought within its ambit-and, I might say, brought within its ambit in a much more extensive manner than they were in the original announcement for assets covered by it. At the time of the original announcement the Government excluded from the tax assets which had been purchased before 19 September 1985. But when the Government imposed the capital gains tax on the assets of superannuation funds it made no such `grandfather' exclusion. Therefore, all assets, whenever acquired, held by superannuation funds are subject to the capital gains tax whenever they are disposed of.

Of course, that is an enormous addition to the ambit of the tax because those funds hold a very high proportion of the total share and property assets held by all Australians. So we have a totally different animal today from that which we had in 1985. That is one reason why these estimates, which the Treasurer has been running around the country spouting, are totally ludicrous. They have no relevance to the situation today. The Treasurer has been quoting some estimates from the income year 1987-88. At that time the tax had been in operation for only just over two years anyway and a relatively small number of transactions had taken place. People were locked in. Again, that is one of the charges that the Government is making against our proposals, but in fact the Government's own tax was locking people in. People who held pre-1985 assets were not selling them and people who held post-1985 acquired assets were also reluctant to sell them. All of the Treasurer's criticisms in terms of favouring the rich and things like that are based upon these figures, which have no relevance to the situation today. They were relevant before the repeal of section 26aaa and before the inclusion of superannuation funds. No valid conclusions whatsoever can be drawn from these figures.

Honourable senators know the old statement about how to lie with statistics; Mr Keating is carrying that to its usual fine art. Yet Mr Keating says that only rich people are affected. That is simply untrue. The fact is that there are 750,000 to 800,000 small businesses in this country. They are terribly affected by this tax, for reasons which my colleagues will develop. There are one million individual shareholders, most of whom are not rich; by definition, we do not have anything like one million rich people in this country. There are four million beneficiaries of superannuation funds. Certainly most of them are not rich, and indeed the number is increasing almost daily as a result of the Government's own policies to give more and more people in the work force access to the benefits of superannuation, a policy which, I may say, is thoroughly supported by the Opposition.

What a lot of piffle to suggest that the capital gains tax is not affecting little people. Of course, it is affecting little people. It is affecting them much more than it is affecting anybody else. As always, of course, ways can be found around some of these taxes; and the people who will find them will generally be big people, not little people. In the final analysis, companies too are simply agglomerations of shareholders. In the end, even applying the capital gains tax to companies impacts, at the final analysis, upon their shareholders.

Small business, of course, is the heartland of this economy. Roughly 50 per cent of non-rural private sector employment is provided by small business. About 2.1 million people are employed in those businesses. The construction industry is 70 per cent or more made up of small business; the retail sector is about 60 per cent made up of small business; the transport sector and the personal services sector are about 60 per cent small business. Employment in those businesses is growing much faster than employment in big business. Over 100,000 farmers are in this category.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the small business people?

—The fact is that small business people are the heroes, and increasingly the heroines, of the Australian economy. But that is not this Government's view. One has only to look at its attack upon the pharmacists and upon the tourism industry, by way of prolonging the pilots dispute through the inflamation of the dispute by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). One has only to look at the recent tax proposal which we were dealing with in this Senate only a few days ago in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1989, to bring forward, as originally proposed on 15 August, the tax payment by all small business people to make them pay 85 per cent of their tax liability within 15 days of the end of the financial year. That is what this Government thinks about small businesses. It has backed off from that as a result of Opposition pressure. We are very glad that it has-but that is its attitude.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that the capital gains tax is just another impost on small business. Peter Boyle, the National Director of the Australian Small Business Association, has said:
Keating's Capital Gains Tax is like a brick wall in front of business investment.
Mr Rick Farley of the National Farmers Federation has said:
Taxing capital gains also discourages entrepreneurial development and the adjustment of asset portfolios which are crucial to improving Australia's productivity.
The capital gains tax is terribly complex. Mr Eric Risstrom, the Executive Director of the Australian Taxpayers Association, recently said:
Even Treasurer Keating must concede that the law (on Capital Gains Tax) is almost too complex to continue as now.

The dreadful record keeping requirements that the tax imposes upon small business will be one of the reasons why, when in government, we will remove it from the date on which the Government introduced it. There is the whole scare tactic concerning avoidance. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) knows perfectly well that that is all rubbish. The tax law has been amended since all of those rorts of the late 1970s occurred, and it was amended by the conservative Government at the time. The Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980, and part IVa of the Income Tax Assessment Act dealt with those matters. We do not want them raked up again at this time.
