SPEECH.PARA: The other remarkable thing about Senator Stone's speech is that he said hardly anything about investment. We heard a great deal about the alleged shortcomings of the Government's policy on capital gains taxation; we heard very little about investment until the last couple of minutes of his speech. The general rationale of the Opposition's policy is that it will change investment behaviour, and change it in the desirable way-that is, that investment will be directed towards productive enterprises, particularly those that produce internationally tradable goods or services, rather than as happens under the existing rules. I will deal with that in some detail later.

Even if one makes the heroic assumption that it is correct that the Opposition's policy will change behaviour in a desirable way, how will it change behaviour retrospectively? Even making that massive concession, how can anyone justify the fact that this proposal from the Opposition will apply retrospectively to September 1985? That cannot change. It could be read into Senator Stone's earlier comments about movements in house sizes and prices that he believes in retrospective causation-that is, that the capital gains tax had some retrospective effect on behaviour-but that was just a bit of slothful preparation, if I may say so. There is no way that the Opposition's proposal can change investment decisions that have already been made and put into operation.

What possible justification is there for providing enormous windfall gains to a few people who have already made investment decisions? I know that the Opposition does not like anybody mentioning this, but it happens to be a matter of public record that one of those people-that is, the Federal President of the Liberal Party of Australia-stands to gain $18m because of his one cent paid shares alone. If the Opposition's policy were to be enacted, $18m would go to Mr Elliott, alone, for investment decisions-if one can call them that-that he made many years ago. Even if there is something to be said about this policy in its totality-I do not believe there is, and I will get on to that in a moment-nobody can argue that there is any case whatsoever for giving it retrospective application.

If one were really desperate, and I suspect that sooner or later the Opposition will become really desperate, one could argue that there is a case to go back to 10 March 1988 because it was on that date that the Opposition first announced this component of its policy. That is a pretty desperate argument, but at least it is something. But the Opposition has absolutely no argument at all to go beyond that point. Under a proposed tax change, the rationale for which is a change in a desirable way in investment patterns and savings and investment decisions, there is no justification for providing massive hand-outs to John Elliott et al for investment decisions that have already been made. All the verbosity in the world from Senator Stone will not change that fundamental fact.

I predict that, because that is such a simple issue, everybody will understand that the Opposition proposal is to give $18m for just part of Mr Elliott's portfolio, which will have no effect on investment decisions of the past. The public can easily understand the windfall gain of $18m to Mr Elliott. The other flaws in the Opposition's proposal are more complex; but the public will understand that flaw so easily that I predict that the Opposition, some time between now and its policy speech, will back away from that proposal. I certainly hope it does because there is absolutely no justification for it.

I also mention in passing that among the recent property acquisitions of the shadow Treasurer is a $900,000 property at Bowral-an investment decision that has already been made. In the absence of any assurance from the Opposition that there would be any change to its proposed capital gains taxation provisions, the shadow Treasurer would also be a beneficiary of the Opposition's policy sooner or later, should it be enacted. I refer briefly to a very good speech by Senator Hill on the subject of taxation. It was his maiden speech in the Senate on 9 September 1981. Quoting Professor Mathews, Senator Hill said:
. . . the taxation system `has been thoroughly discredited as a policy instrument for achieving the redistribution of wealth'.
He said:

It is inequitable in that it taxes some wealth increments and not others. It taxes income to the extent that it increases wealth but not capital gains or windfall gains and results in a heavy bias towards the taxation of income.
Senator Hill was, of course, quoting Professor Mathews with approval. Again approvingly, Senator Hill quoted Professor Mathews as follows:
. . . it is plausible to argue that the taxation system has become a major instrument for redistributing incomes and wealth in favour of the rich.
Senator Hill went on to say:

On the objective of economic growth one need look only at the double taxation of dividends and earnings which is an obvious disincentive for savings and investment. The failure to meet reasonable objectives derives from the hotchpotch way in which the system has developed.

Since Professor Mathews and Senator Hill made those statements, this Government has cleaned up the system. In the face of almost total opposition from the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia, the Government got rid of the double taxation of dividends. The Government has also cleaned up the system with a fringe benefits tax, the non-deductability of entertainment expenses-no more boozy lunches at taxpayers' expense-substantiation, capital gains tax, and by applying the same rules to goldmining as apply to every other industry. On all of those clean-ups of the taxation system, the Opposition resolutely opposed the Government. I note with some satisfaction and gratitude that on all but one of those matters, the Opposition has dropped its resistance to the changes that the Government made. The Opposition either has been educated about the intrinsic merit of the changes that were made or has decided that there is no point in continuing futile opposition to them.

One thing that stands out is this question of capital gains tax. When we add that anomaly to the fact that the specific Opposition proposal is one that provides massive windfall gains-this is a matter of public record-to the Federal President of the Liberal Party, we are entitled to be suspicious. There is not much point in Senator Stone saying that we should not point our finger in this matter. That sort of response implicitly suggests that we should shoot the messenger for pointing out that something very peculiar has been going on. I challenge Senator Chaney, Senator Stone, Dr Hewson-I would not bother challenging Mr Peacock-and any other speaker to produce any rationale whatsoever for the proposed retrospective application of the Opposition's proposal for the delivery of literally tens of millions of dollars in windfall gains to people who have already made investment decisions.

I intended to quote a bit more of Senator Hill's speech but let me just say this: tax experts such as Senator Hill, Mr Asprey, Professor Mathews and, more recently, Sir William Cole have been unanimous about one thing: there is a need for a capital gains tax to maintain the integrity of the whole taxation system. One of the reasons that all those people came to that conclusion was that they knew very well that at the base of the massive tax avoidance and evasion schemes of the late 1970s and the early 1980s was the synthetic conversion of income to capital gain for taxation purposes. The Opposition is inviting the reopening of all those scandals from which it ultimately suffered politically, and rightly so.

Senator Stone referred to statements by Mr Peter Boyle of the Australian Small Business Association wherein he said that the capital gains tax is a brick wall in front of business investment. If that is so, I wonder whether Mr Boyle can explain why right now business investment is running at the highest level ever recorded. It would seem that Mr Boyle has fallen for the same sort of intellectual sloth that Senator Stone has fallen for: their conclusions are predetermined and they do not bother to look at the evidence. So much for Mr Boyle.

To go a bit beyond that, since the capital gains tax was introduced, business investment has grown at an average rate of over 10 per cent in real terms. For the five years prior to the introduction of the capital gains tax the rate was 1.6 per cent. I know that other factors were involved, particularly the very deep recession of 1982-83, but nobody who actually looks at the statistics can honestly come to the conclusion that the existence of the capital gains tax has been a deterrent to business investment because it has been running at very much higher levels since the Government's introduction of the capital gains tax than in the preceding period.

The last point that I will probably have time to make concerns the question of housing. Just imagine what would happen to house prices, other things being equal, if the Opposition's proposal were introduced. People's anticipation of considerable and totally untaxed capital gains on residential property would set off a surge in demand for that residential property assisted-I am sure Senator Haines will mention this-by negative gearing. People will not necessarily save for this so-called investment. They will go out and borrow for this so-called investment. There will be such a rush to do that that the expectation of capital gains in the short term will be fulfilled. Literally tens of thousands of people will be going into the home market-not to buy a house for themselves but negatively gearing to buy a house. SPEECH.PARA: I begin by referring to one paragraph in the excellent editorial in the Australian Financial Review of 25 November which mentions some of the political issues and investment issues surrounding the speculative gains tax which the Opposition is discussing today. The second point raised in that editorial was as follows:

. . . the proposed change could affect revenue even if the coalition does not gain government. Over the next six months a ``lock-in effect'' will take place as investors respond to the incentive to avoid realising their assets until the future tax situation is clarified by the outcome of the election.

Let me clarify the situation for those people who are worried about whether there will be a lock-in effect. For the record, the coalition's plans to remove the capital gains tax, in any way, are doomed to failure. Such a measure will not get through the Senate because the Senate will not be in the hands of the coalition after the next election regardless of whether it gets the numbers in the House of Representatives and is able to form government. No piece of legislation becomes law in Australia until it has been passed by both Houses of Parliament in an identical form. That is what the Senate is here for-to operate as a House of review to ensure that we do not have the dictatorship that occurs when one party has the majority in both Houses, or as happens in Queensland, where there is only one House of Parliament in any event.

Having supported the introduction of the capital gains tax on economic and tax equity grounds in the first place in 1985, the Australian Democrats will certainly not be party to watering it down simply because a coalition government is in power. To do that would take us back to the old days, when people who worked hard to earn money were forced to pay tax and people who got a capital gain, either speculatively, through some quirk of inflation or through something else, were able to get away scot-free. We all know that the people who are in a position to risk their money, to speculate, and to take up the investments that are likely to produce a capital gain are those on the higher incomes. I for one have never been able to understand the back-bench comments that I heard during some of the tax debates last week: that when one takes a risk with money one ought to be entitled to have any gain made from that risk tax-free. Nobody makes that argument in relation to income that is earned by people in high risk occupations. They are still expected to pay their fair share of income tax. To put a capital investment in a separate box is a little bizarre.

In Australia we have a highly inequitable economic system. Incomes, assets and wealth are very inequitably distributed. As a report from the University of New South Wales, released a couple of months ago, indicates, the top 20 per cent of families in Australia receive about 44 per cent of gross income. That is, of all families in Australia in receipt of income-that is most of them-20 per cent receive almost half. The bottom 20 per cent, on the other hand, receive about 4.6 per cent of the income in this country. As a consequence of that, poverty is a continuing problem in Australia. It is not just child poverty that is still with us, despite the Prime Minister's promise that no child would be living in poverty by 1990; it is general poverty. That sort of thing will not be helped by the Opposition's Economic Action Plan-for two reasons.

That plan proposes two major changes that are designed to distribute wealth and income even more inequitably than is currently the case. Consequently, this would increase the number of Australian adults and children living in poverty. The first proposal that the Opposition is putting forward in its Economic Action Plan is designed to reduce the incomes of those people living in poverty and to push more Australians into poverty by cutting out unemployment benefits after nine months. This is the proposal that produced the famous John Elliott line-namely, that the Opposition was intending to take from the bludgers to give to the workers. I suggest that somebody wave under his nose an Australian Bureau of Statistics sheet or any other analysis of exactly which groups in the community make up the long term unemployed. Despite a lot of the mythology in this country, that group does not consist of layabout 18-year-olds.

In the main, people who have been unemployed for nine months or longer are people in their mid-forties, men and women. In particular, they are men who have been made redundant because of some changes in their workplace, and women who are in their forties whose children have left home, and who are trying to join the work force, perhaps because they have been widowed or divorced or simply because they feel able to do it. Those are the women who are not able to find the employment that they want. Those are the ones that the Opposition helped the Government push further into poverty by saying that once the youngest child was 16 years old, the mother would no longer receive the class B widow's pension and would have to get a job or go onto unemployment benefit. The Opposition's proposal is not a solution to the teenage, unemployment level. It is an attack on mature aged men and women, many of whom still have families.

The second coalition proposal which would make Australian society more and more inequitable is the one that we are debating primarily today-that is, to virtually make a capital gains tax payment optional. The so-called speculative gains tax that the Opposition would have in its place would drop the proportion of taxable gains by 20 per cent a year so that if an asset is held for over five years, essentially, no capital gains tax would be payable. As a result, those people who have access to corporate lawyers and clever accountants, and who have the money through their income or other investments in order to further invest, will be able to benefit and, in fact, will stop paying capital gains tax at the end of five years.
It is worth while having a closer look at the editorial in the Australian Financial Review of 25 October this year. It began by outlining the proposal and said:
The speculative gain tax would progressively phase out over five years . . .
These are the sorts of comments that I have just made. It went on to point out:
The coalition proposal would also tax gains made on assets held for up to one year in real, rather than nominal, terms, softening the present treatment.
With virtually no analysis of its proposal, the coalition suggests that the replacement of Labor's capital gain tax with its speculative gain tax would provide . . .
. . . And it quoted, presumably from the Liberal Party policy, `an incentive to save and invest'.

The Opposition is not keen enough to encourage people to save and to provide savings for other people's investment areas by removing some of the tax on interest that people earn on savings. We keep talking about how other nationalities have moved ahead in leaps and bounds while we have remained stagnant. Many of those countries which have a far better developed industrial and technological base have been able to achieve it because 30, 40 or more years ago their governments took the deliberate step of not taxing the interest on savings that ordinary people were putting into banks and other savings institutions. Japan, for example, has only very recently imposed a tax-even then it is a small one in comparison to Australia's-on the interest that people earn on their savings. There are a number of other countries-Canada is one; Italy and France are others-where a certain amount of interest earnings is quarantined from tax. If one earns, say, $800 or $1,000 in interest, that money is tax free. What one earns after that in interest on savings is taxed, but the first part of it is not. That is a significant and genuine incentive to save across the income spectrum that is certainly not provided by abolishing the capital gains tax. The editorial went on to say:

But according to even modest calculations, a speculative gain tax would cause a wave of reactions that would see billions of dollars lost in unrealised tax liabilities, further distort the tax system's treatment of investment and direct a lot of private-sector energy into arranging affairs to exploit the arbitrary phase-out schedule.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those calculations were wrong, Senator.

—Senator Stone says that the calculations by the Australian Financial Review were wrong. Perhaps they were. I have no knowledge of who is right-Senator Stone or the editorial writer in the Financial Review. But I do know that there is a much lesser likelihood of incentives to save and invest coming through an abolition of the capital gains tax than if the Government-either coalition, Labor or anybody else-took direct moves to encourage people to put their money in the bank, instead of spending it, at a specified interest rate that is lower than market values. This would mean that people who wanted to borrow to invest in, say, new export products for new export markets or import replacement items so that we were not as reliant on bringing goods into the country could get cheaper money and would therefore be far more prepared to put their time, energies and efforts into those sorts of areas.

SPEECH.PARA: Instead of talking about a silly abolition of a capital gains tax policy, we ought to be looking at helping home buyers in this country and small businesses which are currently facing crippling interest rates by ensuring that more money is put in those lending institutions, in sufficient volumes for banks and other lending institutions to be able to lend out at lower interest rates than we are currently seeing, so that that money can be applied to developing new products and new markets and thereby reducing the reliance on imported goods. If we are serious about increasing equity, domestic savings and our export markets and maintaining the high levels of high ownership that have become the norm in Australia, whilst at the same time reducing imports, our foreign debt, and the sale of Australian assets to foreigners-something which the Opposition's Economic Action Plan would lift the lid off completely, by the way-we have to look at re-regulating, not further deregulating, the economy so that the Australian Government can retain control of it and so that we can directly assist Australian exporters; those many small businesses out there that are currently struggling to the point of going under with high interest rates, and our home buyers who are watching the people investing in the housing market get a massive tax break while they are forced to sell their homes out from underneath themselves and their children because they can no longer afford the mortgage rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal-National Party initiatives in limiting the impact of a capital gains tax to five years have been enthusiastically received and acknowledged right across this country. SPEECH.PARA: On the rural side, the National Farmers Federation said that the taxing of capital gains discourages entrepreneurial development and the adjustment of asset portfolios which are crucial to improving Australia's productivity. Capital gains tax is seen by many, at a sad time of their lives, as a de facto death duty in circumstances where families are forced to sell assets to meet estate settlements. This is despite Keating's earlier assurances that a capital gains tax would not apply in the case of death.

Superannuation investment people have welcomed our policy as it will limit the amount of paperwork and, at the same time, increase the return to superannuants. One may well ask: Why has there been this sudden reaction, this sudden enthusiasm for the Liberal Party's approach? Members of the Australian Labor Party and its various Treasurers are constantly using every opportunity available to them to introduce new taxes and to rearrange the collective powers to bring forward revenue. There have been recent government decisions to bring forward the payment of pay-as-you-earn tax instalments and to increase the frequency of payments from once a month to twice a month. Such gains will be taxable on a sliding scale over five years and after five years there will be no tax on capital gains. Labor's capital gains tax is producing the wrong sort of investment for Australia. While consumer spending is causing massive problems for the balance of payments, insufficient productive investment expenditure is taking place. The contrast is that the Liberal-National Party looks to the longterm and the Labor Party looks to shortterm political expedience. Here in Australia we have an overvalued dollar, and 20 to 24 per cent interest rates are impeding longterm investment. Labor's capital gains tax is causing a high overinvestment in expensive private housing and real estate. These are hardly initiatives one would expect from a traditional Labor Party.

Since Australia derives its export income predominantly from primary industries and mining, it is a sad commentary on Labor's priorities that taxes tend to discriminate very heavily against miners, and also farmers. After all, farmers generally reside in less expensive housing than their city counterparts. If we use Senator Walsh's argument that the price of land is directly related to the market return off that land, there is not a lot of incentive for farmers to put very much money into expensive houses as there is for their counterparts in the city.

The capital gains tax under Labor harbours inefficiencies and, unfortunately, it is discriminatory. The cost of record keeping is quite horrendous, particularly for small investors who have perhaps $1,000 to invest in a number of market-listed securities. This is the result of the disproportionate amount of accountancy costs in preparing returns for the component on capital gains vis-a-vis other income. Unfortunately, this Labor Party has tended, where possible, to load taxpayers with obligations and, at the same time, take away their rights. The Australian Taxation Office could do well to publish information on the nature and extent of record keeping of the horrendous implications of the capital gains tax.

The Liberal-National Party's speculative gains tax is the first signal of a lower tax regime for Australia. It is innovative with a special five-year write-down on speculative profits. Not unnaturally, Mr Keating is a little worried about the general reaction, particularly from the business community. The business community is worried about the ever-extending tentacles of the capital gains tax. At a recent meeting of the Business Council of Australia Mr Keating took the opportunity of chastening Council members because of their concerns about the impact of the capital gains tax. At the same time, he urged them to go out and openly support Labor's capital gains tax measures. Not surprisingly, most people in the audience at the venue, the Sydney Hilton, saw it as a slur on their independence. But I ask: What is new?

Mr Keating is not alone in abolishing independent bodies that are evaluators of public policy and replacing them with government advisory lap-dogs. Why should businesses continually accept without question government impositions without so much as a whimper? Businesses of late have been subjected to a tirade of attacks on their so-called poor management. Regrettably, many of these attacks have been quite personal, affecting such respected figures as Sir Arvi Parbo of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, who had a confrontation with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in respect of Kakadu. The chemists and the pilots have also been subject to invective because they are not automatic bag carriers for the Labor Party.

The capital gains tax has had serious ramifications for the Australian economy. It has been a disincentive to savings and investment, making Australia more and more dependent on overseas funds. Experience elsewhere has shown that when the rates on capital gain are reduced there is a significant increase in economic activity. Countries similar to Australia which have previously introduced capital gains tax have done so before the onset of high inflation levels. At a time when the Government should be encouraging the restructuring of enterprises, the capital gains tax has effectively locked up investment in low return enterprises and has led to a misuse of resources and to an underuse of assets. People have been discouraged from converting their funds into assets because they fear that their capital profits will be taxed. Rather then internal management action being taken to move enterprises to new areas of investment, nothing has happened, leaving the door open for unscrupulous take over merchants to raid companies. Australia must restore the incentives to work and save by reducing taxes. At the same time, we must achieve a proper balance between direct and indirect taxes, but not in a regressive manner as is the case with the capital gains tax. One commentator on the capital gains tax said:
Legislation has been drafted on the premise that anything that remotely looks like a gain is taxable unless it is specifically exempt and that complexity often creates its own inequities.

Governments all too frequently have been required, under the force of public pressure, to make subsequent announcements of intended changes to remove unintended consequences. This is known as government by press release. Unfortunately, the changes can take up to three years to be debated and passed through the Parliament.

Last week during Question Time I raised a question concerning the anomaly of options which have lapsed being taxed in circumstances where the market value of the shares has collapsed. This is a harsh imposition since, normally, options when taken up become part of the capital structure of a company. Not surprisingly, an immediate answer was not forthcoming. Rather, the only offering was a tirade of insult and abuse directed at a prominent business individual. All too often in this place honest answers are lacking. This evasiveness is part and parcel of the present Government's attitude, since every action and every statement is made for local public consumption and is directed at maximising short term voter appeal. After all, options are really capital raised from the market and their subsequent non-conversion in the case of a share market collapse does not and should not alter their character in the long term. It will be interesting to see the Government's response. The proper course of action would be to amend the Act. However, it would not be surprising to find the Australian Taxation Office chasing after some unusual company resolutions using as its weapon the anti-avoidance provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

The real question before us today is whether the capital gains tax in its present form is good for Australia. The tax has been shown to be no reward for savings and productive investment. That is the key. Australia needs a high level of domestic savings together with productive investment. However, under Labor's mismanagement with its capital gains tax and other taxes, we have lived in an era of greed and extravagance, of paper profits and a public adoration for the wealth gains of the speculative company entrepreneurs. Soundly-based enterprises with minimum debt structures are daily looking over their shoulders as takeover merchants are lurking in the wings. No wonder investment in manufacturing is weak and the importation of consumer items increased in volume by 20 per cent last year. Under this Labor Party Administration, the universities find difficulty in training a sufficient number of accountants and actuaries to cope with the demand from the financial markets. Today, money is not to be made through improving efficiencies and expanding into new markets but through money manipulation and merchant banking. Therefore, all these conditions not unnaturally lead to an increasing foreign debt, a debt that we owe to overseas individuals and organisations amounting to $110 billion.

Equity, efficiency and simplicity are essential features of any taxation system. How well does the capital gains tax measure up to the three universally recognised criteria? Firstly, equity means that people in similar or equivalent circumstances pay the same amount of tax and also that the tax paid is appropriate to their ability to pay that tax. The second criteria, that of efficiency, means that taxes should not hinder but rather promote economic growth and that tax should be assessed on its impact as to whether it encourages or discourages people to work, to save, to take risks and to invest. Thirdly, simplicity means that the tax should be easily understood and not inconvenient or costly to collect. How does Labor's capital gains tax measure up to the criteria of equity, efficiency and simplicity or, to put it in modern day parlance, to the creation of a level playing field?

Unfortunately, there are a number of arbitrary and politically expedient anomalies which lead to distortion. Section 160z (8) and section 23f of the Income Tax Assessment Act exclude the union movement from such taxes. Residential owner-occupied residences are exempt from capital gains tax. This causes distortions. Vertical equity relates to an ability to pay. Farmers often have high asset values and low incomes-living like paupers and dying as millionaires. They also have to put up with some unusual capital gains treatment. For example, one farmer putting a drainage easement through his neighbour's land gives rise to the imposition of a capital gains tax. The capital gains tax fails to acknowledge that the ability of a capital gain to earn involves a withholding or a passing up of an earlier consumption pattern and that, prior to investment, savings must take place.

I now refer to the efficiency of the capital gains tax. The United States experience has shown that a capital gains tax is a disincentive to saving. Australia has a poor record of raising capital. We remain very dependent on foreign investment. Given our parlous international financial position, which has been reflected in two recent financial downgradings, can we afford any further disincentive to savings and investment? The capital gains tax is a disincentive to investment. As such, it is a disincentive to farmers and others to move to more productive investments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact that we are having this matter of public importance debate today and that it is about a proposal in the Liberal Party's so-called Economic Action Plan says some interesting things about the priorities of the Opposition. I want first to deal with what is really being proposed by the Opposition and the consequences of the transfer from the capital gains tax to the speculative gains tax. There have been a large number of contributions to public debate since the economic action plan was released, and I intend to refer to four. Here is an idea for a special, upper-class-only tax cut . . .

That is not a bad summary of what we are talking about-an `upper-class-only tax cut'. One can understand why it would appeal to a party which has a large majority of its support from the disproportionately wealthy in our society. He goes on:
. . . $450m a year divided between a comparative handful of higher income-earners.

When Mr Peacock became Leader of the Opposition, he said he stood for a fairer, more compassionate Australia. This, apparently, is what he meant. It's a great trick. There are you and I telling ourselves that its really quite fair-

because most of the people on welfare are bludgers-
so cutting out on welfare was apparently a good idea-
while Andrew slips half a bill to the Libs business constituency.

But if the plan to abandon capital gains tax shows a strange idea of fairness-

To which I say, `Hear, hear!'. He continues:

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your reductions in the top marginal note of tax-whom would they favour?

—Which the Opposition would not change. As the honourable senator knows, the top tax rate cut is about 1 1/2 times the average weekly earnings and a lot of ordinary Australian workers are paying it. I turn briefly to the alleged benefits of the transfer to speculative gains tax with regard to small business, investment and savings. In fact, only a very small proportion of capital gains tax proceeds comes from small business. That is a very inequitable way of providing assistance to small business. There would be a problem if either the inflation benefit or the goodwill benefit in business were directly taxed. Both of these things I think would be a significant cause for concern. But we all know that capital gains tax applies only to the real benefit and that the design of the capital gains tax provides a deliberate concession for small business in the form of targeted goodwill exemption. It has been structured in such a way that it is equitable across types of taxpayers, that is, pay as you earn taxpayers and corporate taxpayers, and between corporate taxpayers.

The most fascinating assertion of all is that the Opposition's proposal would encourage investment. I am not making the logically flawed argument that one has caused the other; I am not saying that the imposition of a capital gains tax has led to that change. I am simply saying that the overwhelming weight of evidence disproves the assertion that in some way the introduction of a capital gains tax will reduce investment. In Australia we tend to examine these things in isolation, and act as though Australia were breaking new ground, when we all know that a capital gains tax is a feature of all Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. If the capital gains tax were replaced with a speculative gains tax we would see a disincentive to productive investment because people would get an extra benefit if they invested in a manner which generated a capital gain after five years rather than made a continuing productive investment which provided only profits which were taxable year by year. We want to encourage that sort of investment, not discourage it.

On the savings front, the first direct effect of the proposed change would be an immediate reduction of $450m in public sector savings, without the slightest bit of evidence that there would be a more than 100 per cent corresponding increase in private sector savings. The Opposition has made no attempt to prove such assertions. It would do much more to increase our indebtedness than our savings. The evidence indicates that public sector savings would fall by more than private sector savings would increase. It is hard to understand why, if the Opposition's aim is to encourage investment and savings, the proposed tax has been made retrospective. My colleague Senator Walsh made certain challenges about why the proposed tax is to be retrospective. If the assertion is that it will encourage investment or savings, it is impossible to understand how the retrospective element can possibly achieve that. It cannot conceivably have a retrospective effect on investment or savings decisions. The speakers who are to follow me have a responsibility to look at that question and try to answer it. How on earth can the Opposition justify the retrospective aspect, other than to say that it is a backdoor way to try to encourage people to make donations to the Liberal Party?

Finally, I am concerned about the price that Australia would pay if the Opposition's policy were introduced. In electoral terms, I am happy about it because it is working to the advantage of my Party. If the Opposition's tax policy is imposed on Australia, it will pay a substantial price in terms of distortion of investment, which I referred to earlier, and the undermining of the tax principle which Dr Hewson so accurately described when he said that all forms of income should be taxed in the same way. In addition, a large number of people who have gained benefits from the funding that has flowed from capital gains tax would lose that benefit or, as outlined in the Economic Action Plan, a large number of organisations would have their funding cut in order to fund this unfair cut in the capital gains tax. The tax cuts for Mr Elliott alone would make unnecessary the cuts that are proposed in the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service or the abolition of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. It would be fascinating to hear from ordinary Australians whether they would prefer that Mr Elliott received an $18m tax cut or that the Quarantine and Inspection Service be retained.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a debate on an element of the Opposition's Economic Action Plan and, as one would expect, the contributions from the Australian Labor Party senators have focused mainly on what I would call the politics of envy with perhaps a little bit of fact thrown in here and there to try to give it credibility. In answer to some of the comments made by Senator McMullan, who made what I could regard only as inaccurate and crude attacks on the Opposition in terms of its priorities, I respond that the Economic Action Plan comes to grips with a range of Australian problems. One of the problems is that we have people in immediate and severe economic difficulty.

SPEECH.PARA: As recently as last week, reports indicated that the people who have been put under the greatest difficulty by the Labor Party-by the Labor Government of Mr Hawke and Mr Keating which has the support of Senator McMullan-are those people who have dependent children. It is an extraordinary measure of the social and economic priorities of the Hawke Labor Government that virtually throughout its term the people against whom the tax and welfare systems have moved most heavily are all those families other than very low income families. I acknowledge that the Government has been prepared to make some provision for very low income families, but the most recent analyses of income and the impacts of government policies make it quite clear that the Australians who are trying to bring up children are those who have seen the roughest end of a very rough stick from this Government.

After seven years of declining real incomes for wage and salary earners and after seven years which have culminated in increased interest rates which have borne most heavily upon that same vulnerable group of families as well as the small business groups that are the possible and major beneficiaries of the capital gains tax provision that is the focus of this debate, after seven years of treating the families of Australia like dirt, a Labor senator has come in here and talked about the social priorities of the Liberal and National parties. I reject with contempt the contribution to the debate made by Senator McMullan because I have never heard him say a word in defence of Australian families. I have never heard him say a thing about the pressure which has been imposed upon the heartland of Australia, those people who choose to marry and bear children and to bring those children up. The redistributive policies of this Government condemn the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), who is in the chamber, and everybody who supports the Government.

What we set out to do with the Economic Action Plan was summarised by Andrew Peacock in a sentence at the beginning of the document which talks about a fairer and more productive Australia. Yes, we set out to reduce government expenditure by about $2.7 billion-not an easy task, but one which involved our reassessing the priorities of government, and we published a detailed list of cuts totalling $2.7 billion. Why did we do that? We did it because we believe there is immediate hardship in this community and something over $2 billion of that $2.7 billion would go straight to the group that I identified earlier in my comments, namely, families with dependent children. We would have $1,000m in child tax rebates going squarely to the pockets of those people who have responsibilities for children.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or, rather, not coming out of them.

—Exactly. A reduction in their tax would enable them to meet their pressing obligations. We propose an easing of the income test for the dependent spouse rebate at a cost of about $200m and assistance for working mothers with child-care expenses in the form of tax rebates at a total cost of about $820m. Why do we want that novel form of assistance to working mothers? The answer is quite simple: the pressures which are upon families in Australia today require families, whether the mother is a career woman or not, in a great majority of cases to seek additional income. It is an essential part of the cost of earning that income that provision be made for the children, so we are offering some tax justice to a group which has been pressed upon very heavily.

SPEECH.PARA: Some $450m of the $2.7 billion is directed to the removal of the capital gains tax and its replacement with what we call a speculative gains tax. This is a decision that was taken by us a long time ago. We have had to revise some of our tax decisions taken a long time ago because we accept that we must fund any tax relief that is offered by reducing government expenditure. But we said early in 1988 that we would abolish the capital gains tax. We said that the tax discourages longer term savings and investment which are so desperately needed if Australia is to reduce her dependence on foreign capital. We said that shorter term gains will, however, be taxable on a sliding scale over five years and that after five years there will be no tax on capital gains. I repeat what we said last year-was it May? I forget the precise date--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tenth of May last year.

—I thank Senator Stone. We said that these provisions will apply to assets acquired after 19 September 1985 and disposed of after the date of election of a Liberal-National Party government. That is not a new decision but an old decision, repeated on our behalf by John Howard when he published Future Directions in December of last year; it is precisely the same proposal. We put it forward as something which would encourage savings and investment. It is brought forward in this chamber by the Australian Labor Party as something which is there to benefit one main person-John Elliott, the President of the Liberal Party. It is a splendid example of trying to focus the political debate on a personality, to use and ride the politics of envy to the ultimate extent.

SPEECH.PARA: So who does benefit from the removal of capital gains tax? The potential beneficiaries include some 700,000 small businessmen, including farmers. I will come back to small business, because I think that one of the great conceptual problems of the Labor Party is that it has no understanding of what motivates small business and how it works. There are about 700,000 Australians in that category. About one million Australians own shares, and when our privatisation program is completed a lot more than one million people will own shares because we will be encouraging the people who work in the great public enterprises to become part owners of their enterprise through share ownership. Most importantly for the future, the Government has now imposed capital gains tax on a universal basis-not just on post-September 1985 assets but on all assets held by superannuation funds. Four million Australians are involved there, and with the policies which are being pursued to expand superannuation, referred to by Senator Stone in his contribution to the debate, that number will grow. We have heard from the Treasurer, Mr Keating, estimates of huge sums of money-I think, $60 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be $60 billion a year by the end of the century.

—It will be $60 billion a year, up to $600 billion worth of assets by the turn of the century. These are the assets of the wage and salary earners of Australia which this Government is seeking to tax in a whole diversity of ways. This is a country which requires savings and investment. We say that these assets are being overtaxed and that the relief and other things which we are offering, not to Mr John Elliott but to millions of Australians, are right for the future of Australia, a country which badly needs additional savings and investment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party is really saying, `To hell with the commitments you made last year and repeated in May and December in your Economic Action Plan, because we have found one man who is going to make a big profit out of this, who has made some arrangements which, provided he sells his shares at some time, could give rise to a future capital gains tax liability'. I simply say to the Labor Party that that is an absurd proposition. What needs to be examined is how this will impact upon the people of Australia, very few of whom are as entrepreneurial and as involved in large businesses as Mr Elliott but many of whom are engaged in securing their future through superannuation or establishing a small business.

I happen to regard my own involvement in the small business of a solicitor's practice, which I ran as the business manager for some years, as probably the most valuable training I had for this Parliament, because I learned some very simple but important truths. One of those truths is that it is not easy to create and provide new jobs. It is not easy to make enough money week by week to employ the people that need to be employed and to make sure that they are paid and provided with their holiday pay, long service leave and all the other benefits which they are entitled to as employees. I discovered a mysterious thing: when one is actually running a small business and trying to expand it, one actually winds up with virtually no money in one's own pocket. That is not understood by people who have never been self-employed.

The fact is that as a business is expanded more working capital is required and it is found that one's own funds are required to put into the business so that salaries, rent and that sort of thing can be paid. But it is also found that tax is paid not on the money that goes into one's pocket but on the paper profits of the firm or business. The Commissioner of Taxation requires a technical assessment to be made not of the money that is taken away but of the measured profit, much of which has had to be ploughed back into the business. A man might make $40,000 and find that he has to put $20,000 of that back into his business, leaving him with $20,000; but he will pay tax on $40,000. The Labor Party does not understand-because too few of them have the experience-that the whole process of creating the great bulk of jobs in Australia, which are jobs in small business, involves people working very hard over a long period of their lives often for very little return. In fact, a key part of the incentive and, indeed, a key part of the returns is when one finally sells a business, usually or very often on retirement.

The truth is that the Labor Party's capital gains tax takes from small business one of the great potential comforts, the pot of gold at the end of a hard-work rainbow. It does not make sense to people who have been bureaucrats all their lives, working for a salary in the trade union movement or the Labor Party. It often does not make sense to public servants or to people who have been employees all their lives. But the truth is that that is a key part of the economy which provides the growth in jobs. Look at Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, a magnificent Australian company, which in cooperation with this Government has just halved its work force in the steel industry because that is the way that big business and manufacturing have to go to survive. The new jobs are largely created by people who put their own money on the line, sweat it out and get very little in return.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mortgage their homes.

—They mortgage their homes and, of course, very often lose them because their small businesses result in bankruptcy. The Labor party does not understand that this is quite real and a significant element in the thinking that goes into taking the risks inherent in small business.

SPEECH.PARA: We got from Senator McMullan-I refer to him more because he was the last speaker, so his speech is fresh in my memory-a reference to Ross Gittins, who was roundly abused by Mr Keating recently as being a twit because he dared to criticise the Government. On this occasion, because Mr Gittins is saying something favourable to the Labor Party, Senator McMullan quotes him with approval and refers to his `upper-class only tax cut'. That is a gibe that could have been directed at Senator McMullan's Government when it reduced the top marginal rate from 60c to 49c in the dollar which, as Senator McMullan says, eases the plight of many average earners whose overtime takes them into that tax bracket. But, as he knows, his Government delivered very large tax cuts to high income earners in Australia, and the truth is that that is one of the things which the Labor Party did to try to increase the economic efficiency and growth of wealth in this country. Therefore, I reject what has been said by Senator McMullan as simply a cheap gibe.

Unfortunately, I have very little time left to give the answer that I would like to give to Senator Haines's contribution. She made a similar point about people with high incomes, so I pass over that. She talked about the people who worked hard and paid their tax and others who did not. In defence of small business, I simply say that that is a part of Australia that works very hard, often for little reward, and I believe that they as a group will greatly welcome the changes that we put forward. If the Australian Democrats take the view that that will not be allowed through let it be upon the Democrats' head.

I think that this debate involves more rhetoric and politics than substance on the part of the Labor Party. I believe that our policy is an important part of making Australia a more productive society. I thank my colleagues for their contributions to the debate. I hope that between now and the election we will have a little less of the personal politics which have been indulged in yet again today and that a little more attention will be paid to the substance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand Senator Chaney's wish to obscure the issue by referring to families when this debate is about capital gains tax. The capital gains tax has nothing whatever to do with ordinary Australian families. It may have something to do with the sorts of families Senator Chaney mixes with but it has nothing to do with the mass of families that he says are hurting. It certainly has nothing to do with the sorts of families with whom I mix on a regular basis. The brutal unfairness of the Opposition's proposal to abolish the capital gains tax has been well addressed by previous speakers. Nevertheless, I will restate some of those arguments and summarise.

SPEECH.PARA: Capital gains tax was introduced in 1985 as a vital part of an attempt to make the tax system fairer and more equitable. The tax system prior to this was strangling the productive capacity of the nation. It was unfair, inequitable and widely criticised. It was a system in which smart accountants and lawyers earned fortunes advising business people on how to convert taxable income into tax free capital gains. It was a system characterised by the notorious bottom of the harbour schemes. It was a system that rewarded unproductive effort and undermined the equity of the system. It needs noting, in respect of this question of equity, that the distribution of ownership of capital is heavily concentrated among the wealthy groups in the community. The absence of a capital gains tax severely weakened the progressivity of the tax system as a result. It is interesting that the only other reference in the so-called Economic Action Plan, or what I prefer to call, the Fosters family package, is a reference to a reduction in the top marginal rate of tax from 49c to 39c, thus making the tax system even less progressive and even less fair. So much for the fairness and concern that the Opposition is always talking about.

The decision to introduce the capital gains tax brought us into line with most other civilised Western industrialised economies. We were the only member of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), as I am aware, without a capital gains tax. If the Opposition is able to abolish it, and it will do that with difficulty, as Senator Haines has already indicated, we will again be the only member country of the OECD without a capital gains tax. The capital gains tax then is a useful means of redistributing income in a fair and equitable way. Its necessity is widely recognised, not only out of consideration for the equity of the system but also because of the distortions experienced in an economy which rewards unproductive effort.

Since its inception in 1985, capital gains tax has yielded $500m directly and billions of dollars indirectly through those funds which, instead of being able to be placed in tax-free capital gains, have to accrue tax in more productive uses. This year it is expected that another $500m will be earned from the tax, and more will be earned in ensuing years as assets acquired after 19 September 1985 are realised. It is nonsense to claim that capital gains tax affects, in the words of Mr Peacock, `countless millions of taxpayers'. In fact, it is paid by a very small minority of taxpayers. Sixty-two per cent has come from taxpayers with taxable incomes in excess of $50,000. Taxpayers above this level comprise 3 per cent of the population. That is hardly millions of taxpayers and it is hardly the mass of families that Senator Chaney referred to. It is worthy of note that while this top 3 per cent of taxpayers pay 62 per cent of capital gains tax, they pay just 17 per cent of total personal income tax. Less than one per cent of individual taxpayers paid capital gains tax in 1987-88. This gives some idea of the equity of the system.

The Opposition is suggesting, by its proposed abolition of the capital gains tax, that one per cent of the population should have its tax liability reduced or abolished, and that the 99 per cent of remaining taxpayers should pick up the burden in making up that shortfall of revenue which is needed to do the many things that governments need to do. The Opposition plans to abolish this eminently fair tax, which on the one hand gets rid of distortions and, as I have said, on the other hand brings greater equity into the system. Further, it affects only the wealthy minority, who are most able to afford it. The Opposition also plans to make the application of the abolition of the capital gains tax retrospective to September 1985.

It has been interesting to note in past debates on taxation the cries of anguish of certain Opposition members, particularly those from Western Australia, around the question of retrospectivity of taxation. The Opposition seems to be opposed to it where it involves taking money from the wealthy few who were rorting the system; but it is in favour of retrospectivity when it involves giving that money back in windfall gains to the same people. Senator Walsh expressed bewilderment at his incapacity to find a rationale behind this element of the Opposition's plan. I can understand his bewilderment. It cannot be an attempt to buy votes, although certainly the motivation in the rest of the Economic Action Plan is a cynical attempt to do just that. Capital gains tax is not an unpopular tax. It affects only a small minority, who I imagine already vote for the conservatives. There is no widespread opposition to the tax. One is left with the inescapable conclusion that either John Elliott and others who stand to gain have applied pressure, or that it seemed a good way, as Senator McMullan has already indicated, of funding increasingly expensive campaigns. Perhaps Tony Eggleton will be expecting brown paper bags on his desk in anticipation of the pot of gold that the Opposition plans to give John Elliott and the others in the one per cent of the population who are affected.

Senator Walsh issued a challenge to which, I note, no-one has responded. He asked why the Opposition has chosen to apply the abolition of the capital gains tax retrospectively to September 1985. I repeat that challenge in a more direct and specific way: Why is the Opposition giving John Elliott a windfall gain of $18m? I would be very interested in ensuing debates to hear an answer to that question because I have heard no answer so far. The only justification thrown up by the Opposition-in what I believe, despite Senator Stone's plaudits for the quality of the debaters, has been a pretty lack lustre debate-is that it will help small business. Senator Chaney glibly assumes that nobody on this side of the House has any experience in small business. There are a number of people on this side of the House that do, and I happen to be one of them, albeit some time ago. I was involved in small business-successfully. I chose to get out of it; I was not bankrupted. I do understand the difficulty of small business. I have a great deal of respect for the service that small business provides to this nation.

There is little evidence in the Opposition's comments on how the abolition of the capital gains tax and the introduction of a speculative gains tax can in any way help small business. Only a small proportion of the proceeds of capital gains tax is paid by small business in the first place. Less than 2.5 per cent of corporate taxpayers paid any capital gains tax in 1987-88. Sixty-eight per cent of capital gains tax came from the 1.4 per cent of companies with the highest taxable incomes. The design of the capital gains tax provides a deliberate concession, to which Senator McMullan has already alluded, for small businesses in the form of a targeted goodwill exemption. In any case, Labor has done more for small business in the last six years than successive conservative governments have done in 30 of the last 40 years. I refer specifically to quite radical changes but changes which are very supportive of small business, such as the company tax imputation system, which has reduced the tax on distributed company income from a maximum of 78 per cent, under the Liberals, to an estimated level of 47 per cent now. I refer also to the cut in the marginal company tax rate, from 49c to 39c in the dollar, and to the cut in personal income tax from 60c to 49c in the dollar and, at the lower end of the scale, from 30c to 21c in the dollar. There has been an increase in the threshold for wholesale tax from $12,000 to $50,000, which is double the rate of increase of the consumer price index.

Even more important than these specifically targeted concessions for small business is the sustained economic growth which has been experienced over this period. We have sustained economic growth at a rate higher than the average rate for all Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries over that period. There has been a reduction since 1982-83, which small business has gained from, in the real unit cost of labour of 14.2 per cent. There has been a massive increase in the profit share, which I do not hear anybody complaining about. This has resulted in probably the biggest investment boom this country has ever known, certainly in the last 40 years. Kenneth Davidson, in an article in the Age on 2 November 1989 headed `Liberal policy's real winners', talks of retrospectivity in the following terms:

Their present policy of retrospective tax cuts, which is in complete violation of the letter and spirit of the tax legislation as it stands, shows that the principle the coalition is defending is the right of the rich to pay taxes only if they so choose. This principle is clearly obnoxious to even the roughest notions of tax equity.

So what is the justification not only for retrospectivity but also for the abolition of the capital gains tax? What is the justification for its dressed up version-its replacement-the speculative gains tax, which gives massive windfall gains to the Liberal Party's wealthy mates, including the President of the Liberal Party, John Elliott? There seems to be very little justification; it is widely acknowledged. A number of quotations have already been read out to the Senate and I will not repeat them. I simply add the following: The Wednesday, 25 October editorial of the Australian Financial Review stated:

The coalition has provided no rationale for departing from the principle of a comprehensive income tax base in the case of capital gains-nor has it shown that applying some arbitrary time element will somehow favour `productive' over `speculative' investments.
The last paragraph states:

By putting it on the agenda, the Opposition has created a political issue by proposing a weak and philosophically unconvincing proposition. Its policy response, instead of showing some fiscal spine, lacks any philosophic coherence and will harm revenue.
An article by Ross Gittins in the Sydney Morning Herald of 8 November stated:

If capital gains tax is replaced with a speculative gains tax it should take only a matter of months for the tax lawyers to adapt the old lease premium trick to the new rules. Similar stunts can be performed using licences and covenants.

Quite apart from the questions of fairness and tax avoidance, there is another justification for a tax on capital gains: it makes the system more neutral in its effect on the decisions made by businesses and investors.

If some forms of income are taxed, whereas other forms of incomes are tax-exempt, people will be encouraged to invest in those assets which produce tax-exempt income rather than those which produce taxable income.

That aptly sums up the Liberal Party's very shallow attempt at redistributing income from the poor to the wealthy and specifically to individuals who are closely associated with the Liberal Party. One can only guess at the motivation.

On page 20 of its annual report for 1988-89 the Australian Film Commission draws attention to the fact that in January 1989 the Commission engaged a management consultant firm, namely Peat Marwick Hungerfords, to assist in a review of the processes and operations of the Australian Film Commission and to carry out consultations with staff, industry and government. Apparently the Film Commission has had a look at this matter. An article which appeared in the 11-24 May 1989 edition of the film industry magazine Encore indicated that the Commission had endorsed the basic thrust of the major review which had been undertaken. It has been in the hands of the Commission itself for a considerable time. Under the continuing unsatisfactory administration of Mr Adams, the Chairman of the Australian Film Commission, who has just been reappointed to that position for another 12-month period, we have a situation in which the Film Commission itself, having undertaken a review, has not made public its views about the review or communicated to the Government or anybody else what the situation is.

During this year we have had a saga. Mr Rowland, who was much heralded when he took up the position of Chief Executive of the Australian Film Commission, resigned during the last few months. We have not had a satisfactory explanation as to why he resigned-whether he jumped or whether he was pushed. All we are told that he has left the Commission in order to pursue his career elsewhere. The Australian film industry is in a general state of malaise. When I was discussing the report of the Australian Film Finance Corporation a few days ago. All cultures must retell these universal stories for themselves, they must explain them in their own terms. . . or cease to be cultures.
If you do not tell your own tribal stories, you become detribalized. The tribe does not own its dreams and dies as a tribe.
Cultural disaster. National disaster.
Because cultural integrity equals national integrity equals national survival.
Elsewhere he says:
In this part of the 20th century, the great storytelling medium is film, whether shown in cinemas, or on television sets either as broadcast or played from VCRs.
He concludes his essay be saying:
This century began with our ceasing to be a colony. It could end with our becoming a colony again, this time a cultural one.

It is an interesting essay but, of course, it does not tell us what we are supposed to be trying to say by way of what constitutes cultural integrity. It does not address the question of whether we need a regulatory framework in order to support that cultural integrity or whether the process of government regulation-that is, the government of today determining what cultural identity is-in any sense is actually compatible with the very idea of cultural integrity. Mr Morphett is part of the regulatory approach as far as children's television is concerned. Let me tell you, Mr Acting Deputy President, what somebody who is actually in the business of producing children's television had to say. This person was reported in the Australian of 29 November 1989 as saying that the new standards being promulgated by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal were ridiculous and stupid, particularly when the resources of the networks were already strapped for cash. He said that children's drama aimed at the 6- to 13-year-old age group was a dismal failure and that nobody remembers the names of the things that were done. He said:
Our children don't need it and they don't watch it, for the simple reason that they are too sophisticated for that namby pamby nonsense.

The speaker was Simon Townsend, who probably has a record as commercially the most successful producer of children's television in Australia. He has come to the point of simply saying that there really comes a time when two things should be allowed to occur; first, what children watch on television should be primarily a choice made by the children, not by some superannuated adult who thinks that he or she knows considerably better what is good for children in terms of cultural television product. Children do not watch it simply because they are bored rigid by most of the stuff fed to them by the regulators of children's television. Secondly, he says that there ought to be a clearer view on the part of the regulators about what it is that constitutes the sort of cultural identity that they say they wish to protect.

The Opposition parties have taken the view that the Children's Television Foundation is a body that ought to have a continuing and ongoing life; that, indeed, there ought to be proper standards and there ought to be the provision of some quota protection for children's television. But it seems that the Children's Television Foundation has long ceased asking questions such as: what is to be produced; what points are to be awarded; how much of it there is to be; and how much of it is to be `genuinely Australian'? It is a matter of very great regret that while we have the rhetoric about cultural identity, we have none of the intellectual substance about what that means. This ought to have been forthcoming in the annual report of an important and significant part of the cultural and television industry in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
On 15 March 1962, President John F. Kennedy of the United States inaugurated World Consumer Rights Day. In doing so, he spelt out seven rights to which consumers should be entitled:
The right to safety
The right to be informed
The right to choose
The right to be heard
The right to redress
The right to consumer education
The right to a healthy environment.
The grouped proceedings Bill which I am bringing forward today will enhance enormously Australian consumers' right to redress.

The question of whether there is a need to introduce a new form of representative or class procedure to deal with multiple wrongs has been examined many times over the years-most recently by the Australian Law Reform Commission in its 1988 report `Grouped proceedings in the Federal Court'.

As that report notes, in an age of mass production and distribution of goods and services, the potential for loss or damage to be caused on a mass scale is high. While the overall damage may be great, the amount of damage incurred by an individual may be relatively small in proportion to the cost of legal services and court proceedings. Quite clearly, if cost factors preclude individual enforcement of rights, justice is being denied to any individual so affected.

Cost and other barriers inhibiting people's access to the courts must be lowered so that people can receive the compensation to which the law says they are entitled. The costs of litigation in this country are prohibitive except for the very rich and those who qualify for legal aid.

The Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee is currently conducting an inquiry into the cost of legal services and litigation in Australia-an inquiry first raised in this place by the Australian Democrats. The Democrats were motivated to propose both that inquiry and this Bill because, for a lot of ordinary Australians the option of legal redress is not available in practice.

The legal system itself is quite antiquated in many respects, despite the efforts of some tireless individuals. Some useful reforms have been made. The creation of administrative forums, such as small claims courts and residential tenancies tribunals to deal more informally, expeditiously and inexpensively with disputes has proven very worthwhile.

However, the procedures used in our legal system have advanced very little since the passage of the United Kingdom Judicature Act in 1873. An English court of appeal ruling in 1910 effectively closed off the common law opportunity to sue for damages in a representative capacity. Although representative procedures apply in most Australian jurisdictions, they cannot be used in actions claiming damages with the exception of South Australia, and, in certain circumstances, Victoria. Apart from some State and Commonwealth Acts which allow representative procedures, the procedure itself has not been developed to nearly the same extent as it has in the United States.

In the United States, of course, a quite robust system of class actions has emerged. Quite deservedly in many respects, the class actions system there has earned a bad name. In the USA, class actions appear to typify many of the worst characteristics of an over-litigious society. The phenomenon conjures up images of ``ambulance-chasing'' lawyers signing up people injured by poor quality products and issuing units for vast sums of money which would bankrupt companies and benefit only the lawyers.

However, the Australian Law Reform Commission proposals, and this Bill which is based on those proposals, avoid these problems. The proposed grouping procedure differs in a number of significant ways from US-style class actions and does not contain the scope for abuse or potential for high costs which exist there.

To return to the need for grouped proceedings, I want to canvass briefly the deficiencies in the present system. What is missing, is a procedure enabling private action to be taken in case of alleged multiple wrongdoing to secure a binding decision in respect of all those affected.

As I noted earlier, the amount involved in individual claims may not warrant the cost of legal proceedings, and in any event, where claims arise from multiple wrongdoing, individual litigation is not an efficient use of resources. Alternative, less expensive means of resolving small claims are not available in all cases and, again, alternative means require individual action which is an inappropriate way to deal efficiently with multiple wrongdoing.

The advantages of grouping claims for damages from multiple wrongdoing are clear. Common issues can be dealt with at the same time, the cost of litigation to the individual is reduced and a multiplicity of proceedings is avoided. The object of the new procedures is to reduce costs where it is necessary and to promote efficiency in the administration of justice, not to encourage abuse or the pursuit of trivial claims.
The ALRC cites many obvious examples of problems that could have been dealt with by the courts more satisfactorily in grouped proceedings.

Among the problems mentioned are: complaints about misleading advertising by a credit union, which led borrowers to believe they would be insured if they were unable to meet their payments due to illness; asbestos cases, where more than 300 workers have claimed damages arising from their contracting mesothelioma; bushfire cases, in which people have made claims against electricity authorities over fires which allegedly began due to faulty power lines.

Other consumer complaints which could have been dealt with by grouped proceedings include: the case of a camera manufacturer which stopped producing film needed to allow the cameras it had sold to function; a situation where toxic chemicals damaged oyster beds; and where building work had damaged adjacent premises.

The procedures provided for in this Bill, which reflect the ALRC recommendations, amount to a detailed cost-effective scheme for the grouping of claims in the Federal Court, balance the interests of all parties and achieve the goals of access and court efficiency.

Under this Bill, the use of the procedure is confined in the first instance to the Federal Court. This has been done because the Federal Court has developed particular techniques which will be useful in implementing grouped proceedings. After some experience and assessment, the procedure could be given wider application.

There are several important features of the Bill to which I want to draw attention. First, it should be noted that the procedure is a group of proceedings being conducted together, not a representative procedure. To use the Commission's terminology, the proceedings relating to each member of the group are `bundled together' and conducted by one of the group-the principal applicant.

Secondly, the consent of group members is not necessary for the commencement of the proceeding, but a group member can choose to opt out and pursue an individual action. This approach ensures that those who did not know they were entitled to a legal remedy are not excluded from that legal remedy and also retains freedom of choice.

Certain criteria exist for the commencement of group proceedings, including a minimum of seven group members (plus the principal applicant) and at least one question of law or fact that is common to the proceedings of each member of the group. Even if the circumstances giving rise to relief are the same, the relief claimed may differ.

One of the arguments frequently raised against this sort of proposal is the potential for abuse. This scheme has a number of provisions which ensure that the procedure will be cost-effective and that there will be little, if any, scope for trivial claims or blackmail suits. In cost-effectiveness terms, proceedings can be separated by the court if it is unable to deal with grouped claims economically compared with individual proceedings. Further, there is little scope for principal applicants to commence proceedings which have no merit in the hope of forcing a settlement. The court can dismiss the proceedings if they are frivolous, vexatious or an abuse of process. Secondly, the general rule that the loser pays the winner's costs, which the Commission recommends not be changed, means that the principal applicant will be liable for costs if the case fails. This provides a strong disincentive to the commencement of blackmail suits.

Any fair-minded assessment of this proposal would conclude that it is worthwhile, free of problems which beset the US system and long overdue. The reference on this issue was given to the ALRC in 1977. The Commission's examination of the issues has been exhaustive, culminating in its 1988 report. That report makes clear the desirability and urgency of reform in this area.

By introducing this Bill, I am giving both members of parliament and the general community the opportunity to scrutinise and comment on the grouped proceedings proposal. Consumers have waited a very long time for reform in this area and they deserve the best legislation we can devise. I urge honourable senators and members of the public to give the Bill proper attention before it is debated. Support for the objectives of this Bill is a real opportunity for the Parliament to show that it cares about justice in Australia, the cost of that justice and the effectiveness of the avenue that leads to it.
