The Minister went on to say, after questioning by another senator, as follows:
I have nothing more to add to what I said.
Then, typical of the Minister concerned, he went on to say a few more things, including the following:

The strategy is aimed at eventually reducing the administrative deduction system by moving small employers to a system that would require less frequent remittances than at present. I have nothing more to add.
He was again pressed for just a tad more information on this new, and wondrous scheme that most of us were, until then, unaware of. He claimed as follows:
. . . it is partly foreshadowed in the second reading speech or elsewhere publicly that smaller employers may be moved to quarterly remittance instead of monthly remittance.
He said:

That is about 200,000 employers, or half the number of remitters. That is the order of magnitude we are talking about. The change in question is part of the redevelopment of computer systems and it may occur within the next couple of years. That is as precise as we can be.

Not surprisingly at that point, while Senator Watson said that he thought the coalition would need time to consider the proposition but thought it was not unattractive, I was a little less enthusiastic on the grounds that it was not a terribly meaningful statement. Senator Evans had departed from the script. I guess, at that point, there was not much else he could do because the major adviser-who, I see, is present today-was not present and the heavy word was not being applied to Senator Evans's left ear. He waffled on about this new and wondrous procedure for 200,000 small businesses possibly occurring in the next couple of years. Senator Walsh has just come into the chamber, so we will finally get advice from a Minister who knows something about it.

I do not think it is a particularly attractive proposal when we are given something as vague as this. Neither do I continually like to see in this place a perpetration of the practice of making one worthy group benefit at the expense of another. We are told that public hospitals, tertiary institutions and benevolent organisations of one sort or another-groups that are either deficit financed or need to raise money in order to keep going-are going to have their tax payments brought forward from monthly to fortnightly in order that some time down the track-in a couple of years, according to Minister Evans-the Government may change the timing of the payment of tax by several hundred thousand small businesses from monthly to quarterly. I just do not find that satisfactory. We are being asked to buy a pig in a poke.

We on this side of the chamber are being asked to abandon an amendment which had considerable merit at the time it was moved-or we would not have supported it-on the ground that at some time, somewhere down the track, some other people might benefit from the fact that another group of people are having their tax payments brought forward. In other words, groups such as public hospitals and tertiary institutions will be penalised so that 200,000 other businesses might at some time get a benefit. It rather makes a mockery of what Senator Evans said in the first place, namely that the Government does not like effectively condoning the backdoor financing of public institutions. The Government is, apparently, quite happy to condone the backdoor financing of private institutions. I want to know just exactly where we are at with all of this now that Minister Walsh is in the chamber. I understand that he was not here last Thursday night because he was ill. I have some sympathy for him in that regard. Nevertheless, the Committee reported progress so that we could have a better, perhaps even more coherent, explanation than Senator Gareth Evans offered. TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to say that I very much agree with what Senator Haines has just said. I think that we had a false start on this matter on, I think, Thursday night last week when, as has been remarked, the Minister for Finance unfortunately was unable to be with us for reasons with which we sympathise. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the amendment was last before the Senate on 27 November, although it may have been raised last Thursday night as well. The reasons for the Government's attitude were given then, but I will restate them because it will not take long. The pay as you earn (PAYE) tax deductions at no stage belong to the employer. Leaving aside employers who use the tax stamps system, the employer deducts the taxation contribution from employees' wages. At some later time the employer remits the deductions to the Australian Taxation Office. The appropriate length of time within which that remittance should occur should consider administrative convenience on both sides. In principle, at no stage does that money belong to the employer. For whatever the length of time between the deduction from the employee's wage or salary and the remittance of the funds to the Tax Office, the employer is using employees' money for working capital. The Government has made a decision to change that.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that employers using tax stamps are, in fact, paying the employee's liability in advance to some extent because the employer buys the tax stamps before the deduction from the employee's wage is made. But that is now what is being discussed here. There is, in principle, no reason why any employer should be allowed to retain those employees' funds for any period at all. Of course, administrative convenience and cost come into this. I am not sure who was the Minister representing the Government in the chamber on 27 November but that person gave some indication-I think there have been indications given in published material before this-that, for administrative convenience reasons, not in principle reasons, the Government was considering reducing the number of occasions on which small employers are required to remit the money.

I am not sure whether these figures were given. About 200,000 employers are estimated to remit less than $10,000 in PAYE deductions per annum. The Government is considering a proposal that those remittances should be required only on a quarterly basis. These things are under consideration but no decisions have yet been made. As to the question of employers using the tax stamps system, which also involves about 200,000 employers, the Tax Office is trying to devise ways-I do not know what those ways would be; I find it difficult to see what could be done-to substantially get rid of the tax stamps system and to replace it with something else. Only those employers using the tax stamps system have any legitimate complaint whatsoever. We propose to address that. It is being done in consultation with the Tax Office and with an advisory panel comprising representatives of the small business associations around the country, the Metal Trades Industry Association and the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find that quite an extraordinary response. The Minister is saying that as far as the Government is concerned, the tax does not belong to the employer; that it is a responsibility of the employer to get the money through to the Government as fast as possible and that the Government does not take kindly to the fact that the employer deducts a contribution from the employee's wages and remits it at whatever the particular convenient date happens to be. The Minister says that, in the meantime, the employer is using the employee's money as working capital for the holding period. What on earth does the Minister think the Government does?
—It is working capital for the employer. In principle, the employer should remit it to the Tax Office the moment he deducts it.

—I let the Minister have his say; he should now let me have a go. His argument was that the employers have no right to that money; that they are holding it for longer than they need to; they are therefore using it and, perhaps, getting some unfair benefit from it. I would like to point out that in many cases the Government does not own this money either. That is why so many people fill out tax returns at the end of the year and actually get some of this money back. In the meantime the Government has had up to a year to play around with this money. SPEECH.PARA: To make matters worse, having just told honourable senators that he does not think that public hospitals, tertiary institutions and charitable organisations should be able to use this money-although it apparently is okay for the Government to do so-the Minister then said that at some time down the track the Government will allow some private sector employers to have the use of this money not only for a month but for a quarter. He cannot say, on the one hand, that one group of people does not owe the money, and therefore it is not going to be able to have it for four weeks, it is only allowed to have it for two weeks; and then, on the other hand, cheerfully admit that at some time when the Government has finally made a decision about it-and it is not quite sure when that will be-it will allow some other employers to have access to this money, not for a month but for a full quarter. As far as I am concerned, we will not be put into the position of deciding to abandon the amendment that would provide some additional benefit to hospitals, universities and so on, on the ground that at some time the Government might make a decision about benefiting somebody else.

SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989. Senator Macklin has moved an amendment to insert a new paragraph 3 (e). The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Macklin be agreed to.

—I do not want to debate it now, but I table the supplementary explanatory memorandum and foreshadow a Government amendment to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, but it relates to a different clause.
—Has the Government amendment been circulated?
—I thought it had; it has not been.
—It should be circulated now. The immediate question is that the amendment moved by Senator Macklin be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we were considering the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) last week, Senator Reynolds responded on behalf of the Government. She mentioned a number of reasons why the Government did not find the amendment that I had moved acceptable. Honourable senators will remember that the amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 4, after paragraph 3 (d), add the following new paragraph:
``(e) by inserting after item 123a the following item:

`123aa. (1) Goods, not covered by any other item in this Schedule, for use as special aids, and not for sale for that purpose, by persons with physical or intellectual disabilities, in respect of whom a medical practitioner or a qualified or registered occupational therapist has certified that the use of the goods as special aids is necessary . . .

On that occasion Senator Reynolds quoted from a document which was at least two years old-it was not used last year-stating the reason that this amendment was not accepted. I had hoped that the Government would have kept up with the reasons it would not accept it. Perhaps the Government could produce new reasons each year. The Minister said that there would be problems with the administration of this proposal and that it left the way open to abuse. I have already indicated-obviously it has not got through, but I will try again-that that is not the case. For the purposes of proving that it is not the case, I will quote from those parts of the Act that are drafted and are currently in the Act in identical terms to the amendment which I have moved. Item 123a, which is in the first schedule, provides for exemption for interactive and broadcast videotex systems, broadcast teletext decoding devices, and similar decoding devices of a kind used in or in connection with television receivers where the system or device is for use and not for sale by profoundly deaf persons or persons taken to be profoundly deaf. Exemption for this equipment is on a restricted basis and available only to persons to whom a certificate as to the extent of their hearing disability has been furnished. Clearly, the mechanisms are already in place within the Department.

Let us look at another item, item 135a of the schedule, which requires evidence of a disability before sales tax exemptions are offered to persons seeking them. Under this item motor vehicles, and parts thereof, for use in the transportation to and from the gainful employment of a person in respect of whom the Director-General of Social Services, or an officer appointed by him for that purpose, has certified that he has lost the use of one or both legs to such an extent that he might be permanently unable to use public transport are also exempt. In other words, we go through the mechanism to deal with these issues. There is not an administrative difficulty. If there were an administrative difficulty, I presume that some time in the last number of years that I have moved this particular amendment the Government would have moved to take those items out of the schedule. It has not done so in the past, and it has not done so today. The Government is not doing that for very good and proper reasons; that is, that it is administratively simple and necessary. It is administratively simple because the mechanism is already in place, and it is necessary.

As I mentioned in my previous speech, item 42 (17) refers to wigs and hairpieces for people who are clinically bald, provided there is certification that the person has lost his or her hair due to sickness or disease. I do not want to go through all of these items. I have done so in the past and I have no intention of doing so again and detaining the Committee. It is utter bunkum to suggest that it is administratively difficult. We have had that argument out in the past. Let us drop it and come up with the real reasons that the Government does not accept this amendment. It cannot refuse to accept the amendment on that rather outmoded, antiquated and certainly discredited excuse. If the Government wishes to press ahead with that particular excuse, I will ask it to explain why it has not removed the other items. We can go through them one by one if the Minister wishes. I would like to hear the real reason that the Government proposes not to accept this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just had circulated in the chamber an amendment which is to be moved on behalf of the Government to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2).
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. The circulation was not authorised and, indeed, it is the wrong amendment. I have the correct amendment here to be circulated.

—Perhaps you would make it clear to the Committee which is the wrong amendment. There are two amendments circulated on behalf of the Government, numbered 1 and 2. Would you clarify which is the right one and which is the wrong one?

—The copy I have was given to me by the Treasurer's office. It does not have a number on it. Neither amendment has been moved. The amendment which the Government intends to move is on a single sheet of paper, and the memorandum which I tabled about five minutes ago is relevant to that amendment.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments have not been moved yet. Senator Walsh mentioned them and, therefore, they were circulated. The one that he will be moving in due course states:

INTERJECT.PARA: Page 2, clause 3, line 5, leave out `has been manufactured from' . . .
Senator Haines, are you clear that that has not been moved yet?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am perfectly clear, Mr Chairman. We actually happen not to be talking about recycled paper.
—I now table it for circulation.
—The only matter before the Chair is the amendment moved by Senator Macklin to insert a new paragraph 3 (e).

—I am quite aware of that, Mr Chairman. I am also aware of the fact that I have on my desk two Government amendments, which have just been circulated in this place, one of which Senator Walsh quite rightly points out is to clause 3 and relates to recycled paper. You, Mr Chairman, equally rightly, have pointed out that we are not even discussing it yet. However, the other amendment is to the clause we are discussing and it is, in fact, to the same item; that is, whether or not the Government will remove a quite iniquitous 20 per cent sales tax on certain goods used by children with disabilities in the interests of their education. The particular item that Senator Macklin was referring to was computers that have been adapted in some way, specifically for the use of a child with a disability. We have been having this fight in this place for I think the last four years. Each time the Government says `No, it is not the appropriate way of helping people with disabilities-despite the fact that we take the sales tax off all sorts of other goods used by people with disabilities', it turns around and says, `this is a bit of ad hockery', or `It could be used by somebody else in the family'. My major response to that comment is, `So what, if it is going to help somebody'. If the Government forgoes a sales tax of 20 per cent, which would amount all up to about $100,000 a year-and that is a lot less than it gives to many less worthy groups-so be it. The Senate was told last week that this time the Government will not agree to the amendment because it is currently before the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC)-soon to become the Industry Commission (IC).

SPEECH.PARA: When Senator Macklin and I took this particular cudgel to the ears of the Opposition last year, the solution produced was that it would refer the matter to a committee because it was too hard to deal with the third time round. The irony of all that was that it sent this particular sales tax removal amendment to a committee just after it supported the Government removing the sales tax on private planes. In any event I have been informed that the matter is now before the IAC. Its inquiry will incorporate submissions from the public. Those submissions are due by 15 December. I find this extraordinary. That amendment last year was knocked back by the Senate on, I think, 2 November. At that stage the coalition recommended that it go to a committee. We now find over a year later that it will be calling for public submissions by 15 November. I would like to know whether the IAC, or any other organisation, conducted an inquiry of similar length also calling for public submissions when the Government decided to take the sales tax off private planes. I bet it did not. Apparently, hearings further to the one on 15 December will be held. They will be followed by the release of a draft report in about March next year, following which I think there are likely to be more public hearings so that people can talk about the draft report that has come out of what people have been talking about on the inquiry reference-and we in this place have been talking about it for about the last four years. A final report is expected to be forwarded to the Government in July 1990. That is almost two years after this place made a simple request that the 20 per cent sales tax be removed from certain equipment used to help children with disabilities achieve the maximum from their education, hence offering them the maximum choices in life.

It also worries me just a bit that the Government will take its decision following the report from the IAC, since governments past and present have been notorious in ignoring IAC recommendations. I doubt very much whether it will be any more accommodating with regard to the IAC recommendations this time if it does not like them. Why it should be so churlish about a simple amendment to protect the educational and work prospects of a few children with disabilities in this country I cannot understand. The point I am making is that that is the history of what we are currently debating-whether or not the Opposition will support our amendment or whether or not the Government will take our amendment on board.

In the light of all this honourable senators can imagine how surprised-not to say delighted-I was to have put in front of me two amendments, one of which is a Government amendment with regard to recycled paper, to which not only we but also I understand Senator Vallentine have an amendment, and the other, much more importantly, is a long and detailed three-page amendment that includes a provision--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is 6.30 p.m. The Committee is taking this Bill as a whole, but when we agreed to do that there were only two amendments circulated. There are now five different amendments, some to the same clause. I put to the Committee that after the dinner break when we have disposed of the amendment moved by Senator Macklin we take it clause by clause in the order in which the amendments are relevant.

—Before the dinner break I was going through the history of this amendment and I will reiterate what I was saying. This is at least the fourth time that Senator Macklin has moved this amendment on behalf of the Australian Democrats. It is an amendment that would remove the 20 per cent sales tax on computer items that have been purchased for use by somebody with a disability.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter was originally drawn to our attention several years ago when a family in Queensland were looking for a way of making access to education easier for their disabled son. He had been born with truncated arms-his hands were joined virtually at the shoulder-as a consequence of his mother taking thalidomide during her pregnancy. The family had decided that if a computer could be adapted so that he could reach the keyboard-that of course, required fairly significant modification of the unit-he would be better able to do his schoolwork and, as a consequence, better able to deal with his work opportunities.

We had no luck on the first two occasions when we moved this amendment-both the Government and the coalition opposed it. Last year on 2 November when we moved the amendment we had a slight improvement on that. The Opposition, for whatever reason, decided that it would oppose the amendment but would refer the matter to a committee. As I said, I have no idea why it changed its mind even to that extent last year. It may well have been the fact we moved the amendment last year immediately after the Opposition had supported a Government amendment to take the sales tax off private planes. We made the rather obvious point that if the Government and the Opposition were prepared to take the sales tax off private planes they could at least consider taking it off electronic equipment used by children with disabilities. So off the amendment went to a committee.

The matter finished up as it turns out in the hands of the IAC, which is about to become the IC, and has taken something like 13 months to get there. I understand that the IAC, as it still is, will be seeking submissions from the public on this matter, due on 15 December. Public hearings will be conducted around that time in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and Canberra and, following those hearings, a draft report on the matter will be issued in March 1990. A final report is expected to be forwarded to the Government in July 1990. That is almost two years after the issue was sent off for committee inquiry.

What rather astonished me was that some 20 minutes before we were due to adjourn for dinner a number of amendments were circulated. This is not an abnormal sort of practice-we have amendments circulated in this place all the time, either for the Bill that we happen to be dealing with or a subsequent Bill-nor is it unusual for us to discuss amendments that are foreshadowed. We do not have to wait until an amendment is formally moved; if we know that somebody has foreshadowed an amendment. It is perfectly acceptable for us to have a discussion on it.

One of the amendments that the Government circulated had to do with another clause of the Bill-that dealing with the sales tax on recycled paper. As I said before dinner, we have an amendment on it. I think Senator Vallentine also has an amendment on it and the Government has finally decided to do something about that as well. But that had nothing to do with me. That issue will be taken up by my colleague, Senator Coulter. I was concerned with the amendment that Senator Macklin moved on the 20 per cent tax applying to computers.

I was therefore amazed but delighted when I looked through the three-page amendment that came with the one-page amendment on recycled paper to discover under the heading `Amendments to be moved on behalf of the Government' something to take the sales tax off certain items used by persons with disabilities for the purposes of gaining or producing income or in connection with a course of education undertaken by the person at a school, college, university or other place and required wholly or principally because of the disablement.

Delighted as I was to see this, I was a little puzzled since I had not been given any indication that the Government was going to go down this route. Subsequent inquiries revealed what not even I, with my tendency to look for cosmic conspiracies, would have dreamed up. It is this: the Government thought there was a chance that the Opposition would support the Democrats' amendment and just in case it did, it thought it better have up its sleeve an amendment of its own so that it could say, `Gee whiz, we really do think there are some flaws in your amendment; why don't you try ours instead?'. However, had the Opposition done what it has done so often in the past and not supported the amendment, no more would have been seen of this piece of paper. It would not have been circulated; it would not have been given to all senators and we would have heard nothing more about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —However?

—However, somebody was on our side or at least on the side of children with disabilities and the good fairy or an attendant or something of that calibre decided to be super-efficient for the day and circulated this amendment. I notice-and I am sure this is not part of the cosmic conspiracy at all-that all copies but mine, which I had the foresight to take out of the chamber with me, seem to have disappeared from everybody else's desk. But I am afraid the Government is not going to get off that lightly. I have it; it is here, all three pages of it! I will have it photocopied for anyone who wants it.
—Order! I also have a copy.

—It is nice that the Chairman also has a copy. This makes it absolutely official. It is not something I have dreamed up in the mean attack on the Government. I wish I had thought of it, but it was all the Government's thinking, all its own actions, and we now have absolutely irrefutable evidence that the Government is finally prepared to accept an amendment that will alleviate the financial burden on families with children with disabilities and will allow them to be saved the 20 per cent of sales tax on that sort of equipment.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the Opposition for assistance since I understand that even the passage of this amendment is contingent upon the Opposition's supporting the original amendment, in which case the Government will use whatever blandishments, bribes or bullying available to it to make us accept its amendment instead of the one from this side of the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do we have to accept yours first?

—Well may Senator Watson ask why does the Government have to have our amendment accepted first? The reason, quite clearly, is that, notwithstanding the fact that in the past the Government has been prepared to take the sales tax off the private planes, it has not been prepared to take it off this sort of equipment. I, frankly, do not find the amendment as satisfactory as ours. I do not think it goes as far as ours. It is wider to the extent that it picks up air conditioners, which ours did not, but Senator Macklin tonight and on other occasions raised the question of that being something that we were looking to down the track. We believe in beating one drum at a time, and this is the particular one that we have been beating for quite a while.
—Blow a trumpet.

—As my colleague Senator Coulter says, we can blow a trumpet at the same time, which turns us into more or less a fully fledged brass band. But it is important that we get some indication now from the Opposition whether it is prepared to support our amendment or, indeed, if I was sneaky enough to move this Government amendment on behalf of the entire chamber, whether it would support that amendment. The Minister for Finance is now approaching me, which is a worry in itself. It is now a matter for the Committee to determine which of these amendments, if any, is to be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to prolong the debate indefinitely, but the Government will not accept this amendment, for a number of reasons. It was suggested-I think it might even have been carried-a year ago that this matter be referred to a Senate committee and nothing has happened about that. There has since been a reference to the Industries Assistance Commission which encompasses this matter. I do not intend to say any more about it. The amendment of the Australian Democrats is open-ended. The amendment is not confined to goods that are needed for any particular purpose and could apply to all goods used by a disabled person that a medical practitioner believes, or can be persuaded to believe, is for a disabled person's needs. The amendment is not confined to goods for use by a disabled person who earns income or pursues education and, for example, would not be available for goods used for leisure. The term `special aids' contained in the amendment is very vague and has no special meaning under the sales tax law.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been through most of this argument before. If the Opposition supports it, the Government must accept it. For all the reasons given, plus the fact that it has gone to the Industries Assistance Commission, the Government is not willing to accept the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) has said, we have been through this argument before, and the matter is in fact before the Industries Assistance Commission. I do not propose to detain the Committee by elaborating on the reasons why we will not support the amendment, but we will not support it.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Macklin's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having resoundingly yet again lost that amendment on a division I am left with no alternative at all-unless the Government is going to move its own amendment-but to move the amendment that was inadvertently circulated by the Government in its name, which I presume it is not proceeding with. So on behalf of the Australian Democrats I will move an amendment to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 1, clause 2, at the end of the clause add the following subclause:

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Haines, the copies are about to be circulated.
—Splendid. That saves me going through three pages of tortuous drafting.
—You had the courtesy to forewarn me, so copies are now being circulated.
—Well, somebody is thinking.
—I take a point of order, Mr Chairman. I do not think that is the same amendment as the one to which Senator Haines is referring.
—I did not hear what the Minister said.

—He took a point of order saying that it was not the same amendment. The copy I have been circulated with is of the amendments to be moved on behalf of the Government, amendments Nos 1 and 2, starting with page 1, clause 2.
—Yes, the first amendment is to page 1, clause 2, and the second amendment is to page 4, clause 3. The amendments run to almost three pages.
—Do all Committee members have copies of the amendments? You may proceed, Senator Haines.

—This is the amendment that was circulated earlier, before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, in the name of the Government. If Senator Walsh wants to move it, I am very happy for that to happen.

—On a point of order, Mr Chairman: I tried to cover this before. That amendment was inadvertently circulated. I did not authorise the circulation and I am not going to move the amendment. If Senator Haines wants to move it, I suppose that she is at liberty to do so.
—What is your point of order, Senator Walsh?
—Just to clarify--
—The point is that Senator Haines is proceeding to move this amendment.
—Yes, but Senator Haines said that the Government had circulated the amendment.
—I said `inadvertently'.
—Inadvertently. The Government did not circulate the amendment. For an amendment to be circulated by the Government, the circulation has to be authorised and it was not authorised.

—That point has been made clear. The circulation was inadvertent. Senator Haines is now proceeding to move this amendment, or rather two amendments, although she will need leave to move them both together if she wishes to do so.
—Thank you.
—Mr Chairman, what is the second amendment?
—One is to clause 2 and the other is to clause 3.
—I see.

—We are now into that rather amazing, deep philosophical debate about when a circulated amendment is not a circulated amendment. All I am aware of is that the two amendments were circulated. I was told subsequently that the amendment to the sales tax Bill in this area was inadvertently circulated. I thought I had made it clear that I was aware that it was inadvertently circulated. I thought I had also made it clear that I knew why it was circulated, if only inadvertently, and that was in case the Opposition suddenly saw fit to support our original amendment. Because it did not and because this amendment was supposed to be produced only as a flourish in that eventuality and not otherwise, I will now move the amendment that was circulated and attributed to the Government. Whether it should have been attributed to the Government or not I have no idea; nevertheless, it was circulated before dinner. Mr Chairman, you should be satisfied that you have in front of you, and that other members of the Committee have in front of them, the correct form of words for this three-page amendment.
—I am in the hands of the Committee here. Do all interested Committee members hold the amendments? There are two amendments. Senator Haines will need leave to move them both together.
—That is right: amendments relating to page 1, clause 2 and page 4, clause 3. I seek leave to move them together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 1, after subclause 2 (3) add the following new subclause:
``(4) Paragraphs 3 (e), (f) and (g) commence on the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent.''.
(2) Page 4, clause 3, at the end of the clause add the following paragraphs:
``(e) by inserting after sub-item 123 (1) the following sub-item:
`(1a) Goods not covered by sub-item (1) where:
(a) the goods are for use by a person suffering from sickness, disease or disablement; and
(b) the goods are wholly or principally for use:
(i) for the purpose of gaining or producing:
(a) income from the provision of services by the person; or
(b) income from a business carried on by the person (either alone or as a partner); or
(ii) in connection with:
(a) a course of education; or
(b) a special education program for people with disabilities;
being undertaken by the person (either by attendance or by correspondence) at a school, college, university or other place of education; and
(c) the goods are required wholly or principally because of the sickness, disease or disablement of the person; and
(d) the goods are not for sale';
(f) by inserting in sub-item 123 (2) `or (1a)' after `(1)';
(g) by inserting after item 123 the following item:
`123aa. (1) Goods, being air conditioners of a kind used wholly or principally for air cooling where:
(a) the goods are for use by a person suffering from quadriplegia; and
(b) the goods are required wholly or principally because of the quadriplegia of the person; and
(c) the goods are not for sale
(2) Parts for goods covered by sub-item (1)

The substantive amendment does not go as far as we would have liked but it is at least an acknowledgment by somebody that there is a disincentive at the moment for families with children with disabilities to go to considerable expense to try to even out, if you like, the playing field. That is a term we have heard a lot about today. In other sections of this legislation there has been talk about evening playing fields for a variety of businesses, employers and so on. If it is good enough to do that then I think it is good enough to even out the playing field for children who are born with a disability and need some form of assistance in order to mount the hurdles that would otherwise impede their progress through a normal life, perhaps stopping them from having full access to a wide range of employment opportunities and so on. At least this amendment, which was circulated before dinner and has now been moved by the Australian Democrats, goes some way to correcting that imbalance, to providing parents with some sort of incentive so that if the equipment is used in connection with a course of education or a special education program for people with disabilities being undertaken by the person, either by attendance or by correspondence, at a school, college, university or other place of education and the goods are required wholly or principally because of the sickness, disease or disablement of the person and the goods are not for sale, they will at least be able to qualify for a sales tax exemption. It will make the item cheaper and access to the goods easier and hence go some way to helping those people get the education they need in order to get the employment they want.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Haines's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Committee first started considering this Bill it decided to take the Bill as a whole, but there are now a number of amendments-six to clause 3 and one to clause 4-and I think it would make a more coherent debate if we took the Bill sequentially. I propose to the Committee that we take clauses 1 and 2 together. Concerning clause 3 I will put, firstly, Government amendments Nos. 1 and 2-which are consequential-and the Government's substitute for the Australian Democrats' amendment No. 1 and Senator Vallentine's amendment No. 1. If they fail, I will give the opportunity to move the Democrats' amendment No. 1 or Senator Vallentine's amendment No. 1, then the Democrats' amendment No. 2 and Senator Vallentine's amendment No. 2. Finally, on clause 4, the Democrats' amendment No. 3 may be moved. Is that acceptable to the Committee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am curious about the removal of those unauthorised but nonetheless circulated pieces of paper. I wonder just what is the position regarding paper that is placed on the desk of any senator in this chamber. It is extraordinary that pieces of paper purporting to contain amendments are put on our desks before dinner and then, when we arrive back after dinner, they have disappeared.
—You took yours with you.

—Yes. I have been in this place for far too long not to make those sorts of backup provisions. I took mine with me but those of my colleagues who left theirs on their desks came back to find them gone. I would like to know exactly what the security is for pieces of paper that we all leave on our desks. Looking around, the chamber looks like a paper chase gone wrong, as it frequently does. If we cannot leave our pinks and parts of speeches here and cannot be sure our desks will be in the same shambles as we left them when we went out, then I am very concerned about what is going on. Who authorises people to remove pieces of paper that are put on our desks?

SPEECH.PARA: I know we are getting into Alice in Wonderland stuff here because we have been told that the circulation was not authorised; that although this document states it contains an amendment to be moved by the Government, it was not really being moved by the Government, and therefore, it is a piece of paper which should never have been circulated in the first place. Since something was circulated that was not authorised to be circulated, I want to know who authorised it, or did not authorise it, to be uncirculated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Haines, the situation is that the mover of an amendment-in this case it was Senator Walsh-is entitled to have amendments circulated. If amendments he has not authorised to be circulated are circulated-apparently in his name-they may be withdrawn. It is a matter of discretion on the part of the attendants, having put papers on honourable senators' desks, to remove them from the desks. Obviously, it would be unacceptable for the attendants to search through a senator's papers to see whether documents had been filed away, but if they are obviously lying on the desks it is commonsense for the attendants to be permitted to remove them as they had not been circulated by authority. In this particular case, when you gave me notice that you intended to move Senator Walsh's amendment, it was important that what you proposed to move should be in the hands of senators, and I gave directions that the documents that had been collected should be recirculated. The amendment is in the hands of the mover and he is entitled to withdraw it if he does not want to pursue it. I want to make it quite clear that that does not authorise any form of searching of senators' personal documents. If it was lying on a desk, I think it was quite reasonable for the attendant to remove it.

—I presume from that explanation-which I accept-that it is quite in keeping for an attendant to refuse to accede to a request from a Minister or anybody else in this place to riffle through papers. If that is the case, I am pleased to hear it. I think it would place attendants in an intolerable position were they to be reprimanded in any way for not taking off a senator's desk a piece of paper that had earlier been put there, whether it was authorised or not. I am assuming from what you say, Mr Chairman, that the instruction was given from somebody in authority to remove those copies of the unauthorised amendment that could be seen.

—I gave no such instruction from the chair. Senator Walsh was the person who was presumed, because the amendment was to be moved on behalf of the Government, to be the one to move the amendment. I understand that he found that an amendment which he had not authorised had inadvertently been circulated. He asked for those copies to be withdrawn. I hope that I have made it clear that the attendants, acting in the interests of all senators, would remove copies from the desks but they would certainly have no authority to go riffling through the papers of individual senators. If they were lying on the desk they could take them away. It is quite obvious that some copies remained.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we ought not prolong this slightly unhappy debate--
—Bizarre.

—Yes, debate on this bizarre matter, as I am prompted by Senator Haines to describe it. I think we have had two episodes which do not reflect a great deal of credit on those concerned. TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is, in fact, wrong in relation to the proposed amendments and in his interpretation of them. There are really three issues involved in these amendments. The one which the Government has addressed relates to the words `has been manufactured from' and the very slight possibility that that could have been interpreted in such a way that paper which was not made from recycled paper could have been judged to fall within this amending Bill and therefore might have been eligible for no sales tax. The Government has taken out the words and replaced them with `is'. We have no problem with that at all. However, the other two amendments really go to the heart of a much more important matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The object of this whole exercise of removing the sales tax from paper made from recycled fibre is to encourage, as far as possible, the use of fibre which has already been used to achieve the maximum degree of recycling, so as to reduce the impact which paper manufacture will have on forests, water supplies, water pollution and so on, and generally to encourage the ethic of recycling to get the maximum amount of use out of material.

As somebody who is not overly familiar with the technology in this area, I sought advice from a number of sources. I am reliably informed, from quite independent sources who know things about paper manufacture, that in the process of recycling fibre, the fibre tends to lose strength and length and to become rather more furry-that is the way it is described. Therefore the quality of the paper which is made on each recycling diminishes. It is therefore appropriate that one considers recycling in the form of a cascade whereby one starts off with virgin fibre which is then recycled to make it into high quality paper. That is then recycled to make a lesser quality paper. If one wants to keep up the quality of the paper one has to mix a certain proportion of virgin paper with the recycled paper. Progressively, as the fibre is recycled, the quality of the product being manufactured becomes less and less until eventually it finishes up a low grade cardboard, flower pots that are used for potting plants and put into the ground, or egg cartons and the like. Under those circumstances it seems clear that to maintain that level of recycling one does need some virgin fibre going in at the top end. The level to which the Australian industry is geared to recycle fibre is, to some extent, constrained. One is led to believe that the manufacturers in Europe are further advanced than we are here and they are able to make better quality paper from 100 per cent recycled fibre, whereas in Australia our technology is still not quite up to that standard. Given the present technology, it is therefore appropriate, bearing in mind the purpose of this legislation, which is to achieve the maximum degree of recycling, to seek to amend the Government's Bill to remove the sales tax from paper or goods which are manufactured from fibre of which at least 80 per cent by weight is recycled.

That is the first point. Indeed, in support of that I draw attention to the report dated 2 November which has been circulated by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) Who has been carrying out a study on the use of recycled paper by Parliament and various government offices. On page 1 of that report the Minister for Administrative Services states:
The applications for recycled paper made from between 50% to 80% recycled content are likely to be greater than for 100% recycled paper.

In the same vein, the last page of that report refers to permanent paper, high quality paper for archival purposes and so on, identified recycled paper which is made of a high proportion of recycled fibre with a small proportion of virgin fibre and then 100 per cent recycled. It clearly identifies that the paper or other products which include a proportion of virgin fibre allows one to manufacture a wider range of products. If that means-I believe it does-that one can achieve a greater degree of recycling, that is the purpose of the Bill, and that purpose is better served by taking the figure of 80 per cent rather than 100 per cent which, while it is not stated in clause 3, is clearly implicit in the words.

The other amendment which the Minister apparently was not aware of when he was speaking is that we are seeking to replace the word `paper' with `fibre'. The reason for that goes to another matter; that is that paper can be manufactured from a whole range of sources of cellulose fibre. Indeed, throughout probably most of the history of paper making, wood was not used at all; hemp was used for centuries, probably for thousands of years. Indeed, one could suggest that Australia would be better off if it went back to growing hemp for paper making rather than cutting down forests. One can produce more fibre per unit of area over time from that source--

TALK.START.PARA: —Marijuana, and you can smoke it.

—Yes, and one could make very good tobacco paper. I understand that there are genetic variants which have very low levels of THC, so that the paper manufacturers could make the paper without getting high on smoking the paper. Certainly, cotton waste is used a great deal in the manufacture of paper. If any honourable senators are interested, I have samples of paper made from cotton waste. Again, if one is intent on achieving the maximum degree of recycling, one should be concerned about recycled fibre rather than recycled paper. In relation to clause 3, the suggested amendments are really in three categories and not two, as the Minister was saying. I have no difficulty at all with taking out the words `has been manufactured from' and replacing them with `is' which clarifies the situation. I foreshadowed that, should this amendment be passed, I will then move an amendment relating to the 80 per cent figure and seek to replace the word `paper' at the end of the first sentence with `fibre'.

SPEECH.PARA: Bearing in mind what I have just said about a cascade of recycling use, at each step of which the quality of the product, in terms of the length of fibre and so on, is diminished, the other amendment which has been circulated goes to that matter and seeks to allow the products which will appear right at the end of that process also to attract the abolition of the sales tax. Therefore, I will be moving that personal products for women-paper fibre is used quite a lot in various sanitary napkins and such items-egg cartons and seed planters be exempt from sales tax. Those products often are the final use to which the fibre is put before finally being discarded. Knowing what Senator Vallentine is wishing to do in that regard, I have no difficulty in accepting the addition of insulation in that general area because that is another use to which the fibre can be put virtually at the end of its life with a great deal of usefulness. If we are serious about achieving the maximum degree of recycling, we should be supporting all of these amendments.

Surely the intention of the Bill is to protect our environment by supporting all recycled paper manufacturers. Nature Paper aims to provide an alternative to wood pulp by promoting the use of papers made from other recycled fibres. Such industries should be encouraged rather than being priced out of the market because they do not qualify for this particular sales tax exemption. So although the majority of recycled paper will be made from paper, we should not discourage other industries which are recycling other types of waste.

For instant photographic film, or 10 prints, the film price to the wholesaler is $12.44 and the developing charge, developing sales tax charge and so forth is $2.49, giving a total of $14.93, or a cost per frame of $1.49.

I can explain the latter because there is a complication in the calculations. TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it the National Health Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989. This debate will be mercifully short. DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989THERAPEUTIC GOODS BILL 1989THERAPEUTIC GOODS (CHARGES) BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 and 24 November, on motions by Senator Robert Ray:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating cognately the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Therapeutic Goods Bill and the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill. My contribution will relate only to the community services and health legislation. Senator Puplick will look after the therapeutic goods legislation. This legislation represents the fifth stage of an eight-stage reform plan for aged care, introduced some three years ago. The four stages that have been introduced to date have covered, as the second reading speech of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) mentions, the rational use of resources, more effective planning within the aged care industry, the equitable distribution of funding-and there is some doubt as to whether that is the proper term for it-and effective assessment and equity in care provision.

SPEECH.PARA: Some trauma has arisen during the implementation of these four stages. For instance, in the rational use of resources, which some in the industry translate as `reduced funding', the proportion of the frail aged going into homes has been arbitrary and is still being worked through on the basis of 40 nursing home places for every 1,000 frail aged people and 60 hostel places. Also, in the push to get people out of nursing homes and hostels and into the home and community care (HACC) program, there has been frustration in that funding has not been forthcoming in terms of delivering the appropriate services and the standard of care required.

Capital funding is available to only one sector of the industry. It should be remembered that almost 50 per cent of all nursing homes in Australia are operated and financed by private individuals who have made substantial investment in the aged care industry. These individuals do not receive any capital assistance from the Commonwealth, but they suffer at the hands of Government policies which fix their income and then allow interest rates on mortgage loans to escalate from 14 to 22 per cent. There have also been traumas associated with the funding formulas for the care aggregate module and the standard aggregate module. Reviews are to be undertaken in this regard, and I strongly suggest that they should take into account industry concerns. People from the industry should be represented on the review panels.

Also of concern is the resident classification instrument, which classifies patients into categories one to five relative to the prescribed numbers of hours of nursing care they require. The resident classification instrument lacks flexibility and sensitivity. It overlooks the way in which standards of health and appropriate standards of care continually fluctuate relative to an individual almost week by week or month by month. It also fails to address the specialised and intensified care for the ever-growing number of dementia patients who will inevitably be classified for lower funding hostel care, as opposed to the higher cost care that will be required. The effectiveness of the assessments by geriatric assessment teams is being questioned, as is that of the standards monitoring teams. The Government's changes have certainly caused concern in all sections of the industry.

The main part of this legislation relates to the rights of residents in nursing homes and hostels. The Opposition agrees with the principle of residents' rights, particularly where the Commonwealth is a funder to the residents in the homes. Indeed, we are on record as stating that we believe that there should be rules and guidelines associated with residents' rights and responsibilities, but having regard to the individual, other residents, staff and the service providers. We agree with the concept of contractual arrangements between residents and carers. We are also on record in relation to our concern and support for the welfare and care of all the aged, and, more particularly, for their rights in the hostels and nursing homes in which they reside.

As I have said, the Opposition does not disagree with the principle involved in this legislation. Most of the hostels and nursing homes around Australia not only provide excellent facilities but also have a high regard for the rights of individuals, the rights of residents and the rights of patients within those homes. I know there are and will be exceptions-as there are to every rule-some of which have already come to the attention of the monitoring teams and the State and Federal Departments. But most hostels and nursing homes are providing an excellent service and the Commonwealth is playing its part.

We know that there is a need, and we know that the industry supports the rights of residents. However, the industry needs to ensure that the recommendations in the report on which this legislation is based can be put into practice in a way that does not add significantly to operating costs and in a way that is workable and acceptable to the individual, other residents, nursing staff and proprietors.

The Minister has said that there will be an extensive discussion and negotiation process with providers, unions and consumers before the final charter and contract of residents' rights and responsibilities is implemented. This is enabling legislation only. The Opposition stresses the need for consultation with all national organisations-not just those of the Minister's choosing-consumers, relatives, the States and local government.

The principle of user rights is not opposed by the industry but all the people in it maintain that the legal ramifications attached to defining user rights too specifically, when considered in the light of the legal aspects of duty of care, are of such magnitude and have such far-reaching implications-to proprietors, directors of nursing and every other level of staff-that there should be no rush to judgment on this issue.

The Minister has said that he will consult, but his record in relation to this matter has been poor. He has not consulted the chemists. The issues paper on residents' rights, I'm still an individual by Chris Ronalds, on which there was to be full consultation, caused concern and outrage to residents and to the industry, and the consultation that followed was minimal. Only 0.6 per cent of all the residents in hostels and nursing homes were polled, there was a lack of industry consumer representation in the consultancy group, and little meaningful consultation afterwards. It is no wonder that the industry is now suspicious when the Government says there will be proper consultation in regard to some of the proposals.

Following the release of the issues paper and the final report, Residents' Rights in Nursing Homes and Hostels, almost overnight hundreds of frail aged people have become scared about going into a nursing home or hostel. They are worried about the care that they will get in a home. Hundreds of people have contacted Mr Braithwaite, myself and many of my colleagues about the issues paper. They claim that their comments were misconstrued, that the emphasis was changed and, according to some of the proprietors, that some of the interpretations of their statements bore no resemblance to the situation as it really is. The industry has asked the Minister to defer this enabling legislation until such time as the charter and agreement have been finalised. This request has been rejected and has fallen on deaf ears. One must wonder why the Government is pushing this legislation through at this late stage in the parliamentary session.

I should like to deal specifically with the legislative process. At this stage I indicate that in committee the Opposition will move certain amendments. First, as to some of the areas that are of concern, I begin with the charter of residents' rights and responsibilities. This legislation sets out various criteria and provides for a statement, by instrument, of rights and responsibilities of residents of approved hostels. This is subject to a regulation to be brought in at a later stage, which must be either completely accepted or rejected in full. There is no means by which the charter can be amended, if necessary, by the House or the Senate. We propose that this matter not be subject to regulation, but that it should be subject to formulation by the Minister and brought back before the House and Senate where it can be debated and amended if necessary.

The position in connection with the agreement is worse still. The Minister has the right to determine a common form of agreement which does not come back to the Parliament at all. We intend to move amendments which would have the effect of making the agreement subject to formulation and approval by both the Senate and the House of Representatives. We feel it is absolutely necessary for both Houses of Parliament to scrutinise both the charter and the agreement, especially in view of some of the comments we have received on the drafts contained in the report entitled Residents' Rights in Nursing Homes and Hostels. I should like to quote just one comment-from a lawyer consulted by the Victorian Hospitals Association Ltd:

We have given careful consideration to the proposed charter and the draft model contract. In our view, there are provisions in each document which are unintelligible, meaningless or which amount to no more than `motherhood statements' and which do not take account of life in the real world.

The so-called `draft model contract' is one of the most one-sided unworkable documents which I have seen during twenty years in the law. The background material to the contract speaks of `residents rights'. However, there is virtually no reference to a facility proprietor having any rights or, more importantly, any rights which are, in any real sense, enforceable or meaningful. The overall tenor and tone of the agreement needs to be radically altered. Having said that, even with major alteration, it is our view that the agreement is likely to give rise to considerable dispute such that we anticipate it will provide a source of considerable revenue to the legal profession for many years to come.

That is scathing condemnation of the charter and the agreement. Apart from the charter and agreement of residents' rights, there are many other proposals in this legislation. The Bill introduces more conditions with which a nursing home must comply in order that the residents of that home can receive funding from the Commonwealth. Under various provisions it sets conditions that require a proprietor to allow standards monitoring inspectors, community visitors, classification review inspectors and advocacy service employees to enter the nursing home at reasonable times and require a proprietor to provide all reasonable facilities and assistance in order that the people may achieve the purposes for which they are appointed under the legislation. The community visitors to be given these facilities are not designated in the legislation. No-one knows who they will be or whether they will have a capacity of concern and compassion in entering the home and meeting the residents.

The proposed amendments are conspicuously silent on the responsibilities and the authorities of these people. Here, it should be remembered that there is a condition of approval from a nursing home that a proprietor must meet the gazetted outcome standards which refer to the privacy of residents and confidentiality of information. This legislation enables the implementation of a charter of residents' rights which includes the right of personal independence and the right of privacy. Yet, within the same legislation, we have provisions which will allow all of these visitors to have access to residents and staff and to information concerning residents. This is the greatest offence against a person's civil liberties that I can imagine, particularly when this access is being given to people yet to be designated. These visitors will also judge the quality of the care received by people in the nursing home. Will they have the capacity to make that sort of judgment? This provision in the Bill is especially worrying. We would like an undertaking from the Minister that consultations will be held with the industry. Such consultations are absolutely necessary, not only with the industry but also with concerned people in the communities. The standards to be set must be considered.

The Bill gives power to the Minister to approve an operator of a nursing home by the formulation of principles. He is not compelled to do so under the legislation; he has a choice. What is the position if the Minister decides not to formulate the principles? Is he then unrestricted in his powers? Will Parliament ever get to see the principles under which these powers will be exercised? The Bill allows a proprietor or operator a period of 14 days from receipt of a notice that the Minister intends to revoke his approval as an operator in which to make a written submission stating why the approval should not be revoked. The industry does not feel that this period is anywhere near sufficient, given the importance of the situation. If an approval is revoked, does it mean that residents of that particular nursing home will lose their entitlement to funding? Does the approval simply move from one operator to another, from, say, husband to wife? What are the consequences of the revocation? These questions are not answered in the Bill and need some light shed upon them.

Amendments also proposed in this Bill include the removal of the need for medical certificates for entry into a nursing home in some cases, and a lodgment and sitting fee for nursing homes which lodge appeals with the Minister against the fee determinations of the Department. The Minister has claimed that many appeals have been lodged as part of an orchestrated protest against various aspects of nursing home reform introduced by the Government. The industry states that this is completely untrue and that the large numbers of appeals have been submitted because the Department introduced legislation which limited the period-only 28 days-in which a nursing home proprietor could appeal against fee determinations by the Department. The Bill proposes a $500 charge on the initial appeal and $500 for each half-day thereafter. The legislation is silent about who will pay the nursing home's appeal costs and the cost of submitting the necessary information if an appeal is successful. All this suggests that the Department has taken a rather blase attitude towards this provision and is deliberately trying to deny to genuine nursing home operators who may want to appeal any access to that right.
