SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made another of his vote buying, basically dishonourable, statements. This one relates to Jervis Bay. In effect, the Prime Minister said, `I don't care what the facts are about whether Jervis Bay is a good or a bad place for the Navy to be relocated out of Sydney, but for political reasons I must placate the Australian Conservation Foundation and those members of the environmental movement who, rightly or wrongly, believe that Jervis Bay would be a bad place for the Navy to be relocated to'. This is a typical pre-election stunt by the Prime Minister. It is a typical pre-election purchase of votes. But I assure the Australian Conservation Foundation and anyone else whose vote is being bought by this device that the Prime Minister rarely delivers on these pre-election promises. There is no need for me to go into the great list of them.

SPEECH.PARA: This is simply a disgraceful vote-buying decision because the environmental impact study (EIS) has not been presented to the Government and has not been to Cabinet. As I say, neither we in this chamber nor the Prime Minister know the consequences of not only the environmental impact study but also all the other studies that are being undertaken into Jervis Bay. We do not know what they show. But the Prime Minister does not care what they show. Today he made this statement:

Already the EIS processes have thrown up a number of serious environmental impacts that would be associated with a move of the Sydney based naval fleet to Jervis Bay. Moreover, the costs of moving the Sydney fleet base to Jervis Bay would be very high indeed. We will be putting alternative sites to environmental and economic analysis. But I can inform you that the Government is no longer disposed to move the Sydney naval fleet to Jervis Bay.

`Is no longer disposed to'. Is that a real undertaking by this Government? Is that a genuine, fair dinkum commitment by the Prime Minister? He does not say, `I promise you there will never be a naval base in Jervis Bay'; he just says, `The Government is no longer disposed to move the naval fleet to Jervis Bay'. This is a typical Hawke pre-election stunt which has proved in the past to be dishonourable and it will be dishonourable once again. It will be dishonoured, as they all are.

I simply want to remind the Senate that the EIS process, according to Mr Hawke, has thrown up a number of serious environmental impacts. I have seen the leaked letters that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) authorised to be leaked. He happily admitted so; he said that there was nothing wrong in doing it. The letters from the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories which were leaked in fact basically concentrate in their attacks on the environmental impact statement and say that that EIS does not look at alternative sites well enough; in fact, it does not look at them at all. To my knowledge, and to the Prime Minister's knowledge, by the way, the EIS itself has not thrown up these doubts. Honourable senators will notice his careful wording; `The EIS processes have thrown up'; in other words, letter from the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories ministry-no doubt suiting Senator Richardson's newly found green colour and his political nose, which is also turning green-are the motive for this pre-election stunt. As a result the multi-millions of dollars being spent on the EIS statement have already been spent by the departments concerned-the department responsible for construction, as well as the Navy.

The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and others are doing research on this score. Why go ahead with it? Why should multi-millions of dollars of taxpayers' money be spent if a decision is going to be made by this Prime Minister on political grounds anyway that do not matter, that do not relate in any way to the results of any of those studies? That is the essential thing. The statement by the Prime Minister today, appropriately enough, addressed to the Australian Conservation Foundation, is based not on any factual evidence but on political necessity as he sees it.
Let us go back and remember why this whole thing came up in the first place. Back in October 1985 the following was stated in a newspaper report:
The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, said in Sydney yesterday that he had proposed the move-
that is, of the Navy from Sydney to Jervis Bay-
when he began using Kirribilli House . . .

We all know that he spends all of his time in Kirribilli House, at the taxpayers' expense, when in Sydney. It is supposed to be the facility available to visiting dignitaries, but they can never get into it because the Prime Minister is there all the time. The article continues:
he had proposed the move when he began using Kirribilli House, the Prime Minister's official Sydney residence.
That is how it is described these days. It goes on:

Mr Hawke said: `I looked out across Sydney Harbour and it just struck me as an absurdity in this day and age that you should have a major naval concentration in the middle of a great populous city like this'.
It also interrupted his view.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that before or after the 1985 election?

—That was in October 1985, after the 1984 election. I stress that the Prime Minister took the credit for suggesting that the Navy go to Jervis Bay, so I suppose in some quaint, illogical way he is entitled to take the credit for sort of saying `Maybe it will not' just before another election.
—He won't be in Kirribilli House for too long.

—As Senator Tambling says, he will not be in Kirribilli House for much longer anyway, so he does not care whether the view will be improved by the removal of the Navy base. I take that point. What is interesting is that Mr Hawke said:

SPEECH.PARA: I hope, on the basis of the report that we get, we will be able to initiate the moves in the relatively near future.

What has changed since Mr Hawke decided that the Navy should go to Jervis Bay? One thing has changed-the green vote. Senator Richardson is buying it. He has convinced the Prime Minister to that effect. I remind the Senate that the statement that was made in November 1985 was a joint statement by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the then Premier of New South Wales, Mr Wran. That statement related both to the armament facility and the rest of the Navy's bases leaving Sydney. It is interesting to note that Mr Hawke did not mention armaments in his statement today. It no doubt means that while the naval fleet base is not to be moved to Jervis Bay-or may not be, or he is not disposed to move it-he did not say how he was disposed in the matter of the armament facility, which is to involve a wharf on the north-eastern side of Jervis Bay, and a large armament facility in the north-western hinterland, in a forest area. There is no mention of armaments. So before people start saying, `Isn't it marvellous that the Government has blocked the Navy going to Jervis Bay?', they had better have a close look at what Mr Hawke's statement really means. There is no doubt in my mind that it does not mean any change in the proposal for the armament facility. I notice that in the November 1985 release Mr Hawke did not say, `The Government may move the armament facility', or, `Subject to examination, it may be moved'. The statement read:
The largest waterfront site occupied by the Defence Force in Sydney is to be relinquished . . . for civilian use in the early 1990s.

There are no ifs, buts or maybes-it is to be relinquished by the Commonwealth for civilian use in the early 1990s. The statement was announced jointly by Messrs Hawke and Wran at a news conference on board HMAS Adelaide, in Sydney, on 17 November 1985. The statement continues:
The site, which covers about 260 hectares on the Parramatta River at Silverwater, presently houses the Navy's Newington, Ammunition Depot which is to be moved to the Jervis Bay area.

There are no ifs, buts or maybes. It was also mentioned in the statement that the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, had established a study group in the Department of Defence to examine all significant issues and options associated with the relocation of other naval facilities in Sydney, including its possible timing. That, of course, was what led to the suggestion that the whole of the Navy's base operation move to Jervis bay. Let us see why Jervis Bay was chosen, as a result of this inquiry. The Navy's own document reads:

For operational reasons, a future Fleet Base needs to be within 300 nautical miles of Sydney's dockyard facilities. Harbours within the area are Port Stephens, Newcastle, Botany Bay, Port Kembla, Jervis Bay and Twofold Bay.

Port Stephens has no available land. Newcastle and Port Kembla harbours are too small to accommodate both Naval operations and merchant shipping. Botany Bay is fully developed. Twofold Bay is occupied by the woodchip industry.
Jervis Bay is the only port that can accommodate both the proposed Fleet Base and the Armaments Depot Wharf.

So now we see what it is all about. Twofold Bay was omitted, the Navy said, because it was already occupied by the woodchip industry. It looks as though Senator Richardson will get two for the price of one. He is going to knock woodchips out of Twofold Bay and whack the Navy in: strike two to Senator Richardson! That is all very useful except that it means that the Navy has been sabotaged by the Government and, in particular, by the Minister of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. When the announcement was made today, the Navy at operational level did not know about it. It had to be told by the media of this great decision. The Navy document continues:

Of all the locations, only Jervis Bay satisfactorily met all the strategic and operational requirements. A very thorough study was commenced to detail what moving Navy facilities to Jervis Bay would mean for the environment and people.

The relocation proposals have, since 1987, been studied under Department of Defence contracts by thirty groups of experts from different bodies, including the CSIRO, the New South Wales Fisheries Research Institute, and the ANU. The major areas of detailed study are:
* Social and economic impact
* Archaeology and anthropology
* Geology and resources
* Engineering and planning
* Meteorology and air pollution
* Landscaping and visual impacts
* Terrestrial ecology
* Marine ecology
* Naval requirements
* Risk and Hazard
* Acoustics and noise
* Public attitudes
Separate studies of these subjects have been done for both proposals.
That statement recognises that there are two proposals-that involving the armaments depot and that for moving the whole fleet. The document continues:
The combined effect of both proposals has also been studied. A good deal of time and effort has been spent so that nothing important has been overlooked.

This is the crux of the matter: two distinct, clear proposals have been made, yet when the Navy wanted its environmental impact study done on the armaments depot, the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories said that the study should be done for both proposals. In other words, the armaments depot proposal was submerged into that proposal for the whole fleet moving there. The result of that has been to delay the simple, straightforward proposal about moving the armaments depot to Jervis Bay and everything is apparently now up in the air. The assertion by the Prime Minister-not that it `may' or `would' be done, but that it `will' be done-is now apparently at some kind of risk, and we do not know what the merits or otherwise of the Navy's moving to Jervis Bay are, as neither we nor Mr Hawke have seen the environmental impact study.
When the Prime Minister gave an undertaking about the move in November 1985, his undertaking to the people of Australia was not in terms of the environment; it was this:
I give the undertaking that the changes that we believe ought to be made will not, in any sense, be made at the expense of proper defence considerations.

I would now like the Prime Minister to restate that commitment because it appears to have gone by the wayside. Now we have a commitment to a green vote instead of a commitment not to do anything at the expense of proper defence considerations. In the purchase of votes by the Government in the run-up to an election, that commitment has been lost. I condemn the Prime Minister, firstly, for the phoney nature of his statement, which does not provide what it appears to provide in terms of any sense of commitment; it simply says he is no longer disposed to move the fleet and says nothing about the armaments depot. The statement is based on a total lack of knowledge of the environmental impact.

In conclusion, we have a desperate Prime Minister buying votes by promising or saying anything at all, whether it rests on facts or not. In this case, surely the people of Australia are entitled to see the environmental impact statement, to be able to participate in discussion on it, before this kind of unilateral and dishonourable statement goes out as a simple and disgraceful attempt to buy votes.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 May 1989 (Hansard, page 2572), Senator Knowles asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning a statement by the Minister for Employment and Education Services on the responsibility of banks to borrowers for housing. I undertook to investigate the statement. The Treasurer has supplied the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government does not direct banks as to the amounts which they should lend for housing or other specific purposes, or as to the interest rates at which they should lend. Those are commercial matters for banks to decide. This Government's policy has been to create, through deregulation and the entry of foreign banks, conditions in which banks are moved by competitive forces to operate as efficiently as possible. As a result banks have had to provide a wider range of services to their customers and compete more for their business. As well, the establishment of an Ombudsman for the banking industry will put additional pressure on the banks to be properly attuned to the needs of their customers.
